headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Southwest Airlines Fourth Quarter and Annual 2015 Conference Call. My name is Tom and I will be moderating today's conference. This call is being recorded, and a replay will be available on southwest.com in the Investor Relations section. A
componenttext: Welcome to the Southwest Airlines Fourth Quarter and Annual 2015 Conference Call. My name is Tom and I will be moderating today's conference. This call is being recorded, and a replay will be available on southwest.com in the Investor Relations section. At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to Ms. Marcy Brand, Senior Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, ma'am.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to today's call to discuss our fourth quarter 2015 results. Joining me on the call today, we have Gary Kelly, Chairman, President and CEO; Tammy Romo, Executive Vice President and CFO; Bob Jordan, Ex
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to today's call to discuss our fourth quarter 2015 results. Joining me on the call today, we have Gary Kelly, Chairman, President and CEO; Tammy Romo, Executive Vice President and CFO; Bob Jordan, Executive Vice President and Chief Commercial Officer; Mike Van De Ven, Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer.
Please note today's call will include forward-looking statements, and because these statements are based on the company's current intent, expectations and projections, they are not guarantees of future performance and a variety of factors could cause actual results to differ materially. As this call will include references to non-GAAP results excluding special items, please refer to this morning's press release in the Investor Relations section of southwest.com for further information regarding forward-looking statements and reconciliations of non-GAAP results to GAAP results.
At this time, I'd like to go ahead and turn the call over to Gary for opening remarks.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Marcy, and thanks, everybody, for joining us today for our year-end 2015 earnings call. This was another superb and critical year for Southwest, and I am very grateful to all of our people for their hard work. I want to especially thank them fo
componenttext:
Thank you, Marcy, and thanks, everybody, for joining us today for our year-end 2015 earnings call. This was another superb and critical year for Southwest, and I am very grateful to all of our people for their hard work. I want to especially thank them for these terrific results. 
Tammy is going to take us through the quarter, but I want to offer up not a comprehensive overview but at least a few highlights. Of course, this was, by far, our best year of earnings in our entire history, and that includes a record return on invested capital of 32.7%. We no doubt benefited from 29% lower economic jet fuel prices. Obviously, that was a major component of our earnings, but so were record load factors and our revenues were up also a very solid 5.6%. 
It was a strategic year for us in that we had secular growth opportunities out of Dallas arising from the repeal of the Wright Amendment, and of course, that has been a phenomenal success. We've also had secular growth opportunities out of Washington Reagan and LaGuardia that is arising from the acquisition of slots. It was also a year that followed the -- at the end of 2014 the completion of the AirTran acquisition and integration. A lot of new markets resulted from that. And then, of course, it was also a year where we had a unique opportunity in which to build an international terminal and launch international flights out of Houston Hobby. That was for the first time since 1969, by the way.
All of that added up to capacity growth of 7.2%, and then of course, we were delighted that traffic was stronger than that, it grew 8.8%. And as a backdrop, the economy for last year was solid. Travel demand was solid, and of course, energy prices moved even lower. So the convergence of all of these things made 2015 a very successful year, but again, one that was also very strategic for us. 
And we accomplished virtually everything that we set out to do. In some cases where we didn't, we at least made significant progress. I'm very happy about that but certainly that includes generating record operating cash flow, strong free cash flow. And we also returned a record $1.4 billion to shareholders in the form of share repurchases and dividends. 
So I want to make sure that I highlight 2 announcements from this morning's release. First of all, we announced that we will soon launch a $500 million accelerated share repurchase program. I'm sure you all saw that. And then second, we recently ordered 33 new 737-800s from Boeing, and that is spread out for delivery in '16, '17 and '18. And the sole purpose for that is to accelerate further the retirement of our classic fleet. So mechanically, we did that by exercising 6 options and then on top of that, we placed new orders for 27 more. So you get to 33 more new airplanes. 
And then in addition to that on our fleet chart, you'll also see that we have committed to 2 more used aircraft. But I just want to reiterate that our capacity plans for the next 5 years are essentially unchanged by this announcement. We're replacing the classics with next-generation airplanes. And then, in particular, our capacity plans for 2016 are unchanged, and we still plan to grow this year between 5% and 6%.
So the financial operations and customer service effects of this fleet announcement are all very favorable, and Tammy will take us through all that.
Work continues along 3 basic themes this year as far as investment goes for the future: One, as we have significant airport renovation and infrastructure projects underway across the country, some we're managing, some we're not but big project in LAX, Fort Lauderdale, Chicago, Midway and New Orleans. And that Fort Lauderdale in particular will bring on new capacity for us in 2017. 
Number two, we've got a significant commercial technology program underway. And the headline on that, of course, is the replacement of our reservation system, and that's also targeted for 2017. 
And then finally, we have a major program underway with our operations technology. And the headline on that is the new 737 MAX, along with other very significant technology improvements that Mike Van De Ven has planned. And that has also a 2017 deliverable at least with respect to the MAX. 
So for this year, in addition to our focus on these investment programs, we want to do a handful of things. We want to continue to manage our network growth and mature our developing markets; number two, we want to compete vigorously in an increasingly competitive environment; number three, we want to continue to work on and improve our reliability of our operations. 
Next, we want to continue our focus on the hospitality of our customer service. And through all of this, we want to continue to grow our unit revenues, our margins and our earnings. So there's nothing really fancy about that or 2016, pretty basic blocking and tackling things but clearly, 2017 is shaping up to be a pretty big year for Southwest Airlines.
I just want to highlight for our Southwest people finally that our profit sharing for 2015 will eclipse last year's record and increase by 74% to an all-time record of $620 million. And I'm very pleased about that. I'm very proud of them and their hard work. And I'm very pleased with their being justly rewarded with that. 
So Tammy with that quick overview, I'd love to turn it over to you and have you take us through the quarter

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, thank you, Gary, and welcome, everyone. We are very pleased to report a banner year of record performance in 2015, representing our 43rd consecutive year of profits. Our annual earnings, excluding special items, were a record $2.4 billion or $3
componenttext:
All right, thank you, Gary, and welcome, everyone. We are very pleased to report a banner year of record performance in 2015, representing our 43rd consecutive year of profits. Our annual earnings, excluding special items, were a record $2.4 billion or $3.52 per diluted share, which was an increase of 75% year-over-year. 
Our fourth quarter performance was also record-setting, representing our 11th consecutive quarter of profit. Fourth quarter net income, excluding special items, increased 46% year-over-year to $591 million or $0.90 per share, which was in line with consensus. 
Operating income, excluding special items, was a record $992 million, which produced a 5-point improvement in operating margin of 19.9%, which is the best fourth quarter margin performance we've seen since 1978. And it's also worth noting like last quarter, with and without the benefit of substantially lower fuel prices, our earnings and margins improved year-over-year. 
And the record that really stands out is our pretax return on invested capital, excluding special items, of 32.7%. I'd like to congratulate all of our outstanding employees on these fantastic results. And like Gary, thrilled we can reward our employees with a record-breaking profit sharing of $620 million for 2015.
Our total operating revenues in fourth quarter were a record $5 billion, up 7.5% year-over-year on a capacity increase of 8.4%. Passenger revenues were also a record $4.6 billion. Demand for our low fares remained very strong throughout the quarter, resulting in more than 11% growth in traffic and an all-time fourth quarter record high load factor. 
A softer yield environment resulted in a 7% decline in passenger revenue yield and an $8 decrease in our average fare. Our fourth quarter operating revenues included a $125 million net benefit from the amended Chase contract and the required accounting treatment. And this $125 million benefit was about a 2- to 3-point improvement to RASM.
For 2016, we expect to realize a year-over-year incremental benefit from the amended Chase agreement and accounting change. But once we reach third quarter, we will, of course, lapse the year-over-year benefit. For our first quarter 2016, our estimated incremental benefit is approximately $110 million, and that is included in the RASM guidance that we provided. Our developmental markets continued to perform in line with our expectations. And Dallas continues to outperform the system on margins and returns.
International is also developing as planned, including our inaugural service from Houston, which was launched during the fourth quarter. Our fourth quarter RASM declined 0.7%, which was in line with our guidance. Considering a 1-point [ph] impact from development markets and roughly 2-point impact from increased gauge and stage, we're very pleased with our fourth quarter record and lastly, industry-leading revenue performance.
Thus far in January, demand for our low fares remains strong. Soft yet stable yields have continued thus far into first quarter. And based on our current bookings and revenue trends, we are estimating first quarter 2016 RASM will be flat year-over-year. In light of the current yield environment, we're very pleased with our first quarter revenue outlook at this juncture.
Our freight and other revenue production was also favorable. In addition to the incremental benefit from the amended Chase card that I mentioned earlier, our ancillary revenue production was strong, led by growth in earlybird and our upgraded boarding revenues. And we currently expect first quarter 2016 freight and other revenues to be comparable with fourth quarter 2015.
I'll turn to our cost performance now. And our fourth quarter unit cost, excluding special items, decreased just under 7% year-over-year due to substantially lower fuel prices and cost control, particularly our fleet modernization effort. Our economic fuel costs decreased almost $200 million year-over-year, and that was driven by the 23% decline in fuel prices. With the current state of the oil market and oversupply situation, we currently expect another year-over-year decline in first quarter and full year 2016 economic fuel costs.
Based on our current hedge portfolio for this year and market prices as of last Friday, we expect our first quarter fuel price to be approximately $1.70 per gallon. And I'll also provide you our estimates by quarter here. Second quarter is expected to be approximately $1.60 per gallon. And second half, we expect that to be in the $1.80 to $1.95 per gallon range again based on last Friday. And that brings us to a full year 2016 fuel price per gallon in the $1.70 to $1.75 range.
So while above market prices, we're still benefiting from lower fuel prices and currently estimate over $500 million in economic fuel savings this year. Our first quarter 2016 estimated fuel price per gallon is below last year's $2 per gallon and represents the lowest economic fuel price we've realized since third quarter of 2006. 
With respect to our hedge book, our strong profit -- our strong profit margins today call for a more conservative approach to hedging in this environment, in this low fuel environment. We will continue to manage our existing portfolio to minimize costs as we burn off our 2016 and 2017 positions. Prospectively, we'll focus on catastrophic protection with no downside risk, particularly in this environment. For 2018, as we reported, we are 35% hedged and that's with all calls and call spreads. So while our hedging philosophy has not changed, our tactics have in this environment. And we will manage through our portfolio and this fourth quarter of 2015, we participated in 85% of the market decline.
So I'll take you through our nonfuel costs quickly. Excluding fuel and special items, our unit costs were flat, including a 36% year-over-year increase in profit sharing that our employees earned for fourth quarter 2015. Profit sharing expense accrued in the fourth quarter was $136 million. And that brings again the total for the year to an astounding $620 million, which again was 75% year-over-year. 
Excluding profit sharing and special items, our nonfuel unit costs decreased 1.1% year-over-year, which was towards the more favorable end of our cost guidance due primarily to reduction in advertise spend and lower airport costs than we had expected. 
Our fleet modernization produced the expected $700 million in EBIT this year, and that's even with the drop in fuel prices. So based on our current cost trends, we expect first quarter 2016 CASM, excluding fuel, special items and profit sharing, to increase approximately 2% year-over-year. And keep in mind that roughly 1 point of the year-over-year increase is driven by accelerated depreciation, which, of course, is a noncash charge from our recent decision to accelerate the retirement of the classic fleet that Gary took you through.
For our full year 2016, we are currently estimating a 1% year-over-year increase in our unit costs, excluding fuel, special items and profit sharing. And again, this modest cost inflation is almost entirely driven by the accelerated depreciation. And as a quick reminder, as we noted in our press release this morning, this cost guidance only reflects current labor contracts. Therefore, it does not include the impact from the tentative agreement currently out for vote with our ramp operations provisioning and cargo vote.
I'll move to our balance sheet and cash flow. And of course, our balance sheet and cash flows remain very strong. We ended the quarter with $3.1 billion in cash and short-term investments, and that's after [indiscernible] being $835 million in cash collateral to third parties. We generated $3.2 billion in operating cash flow in 2015 and incurred $2 billion in capital expenditures. For 2016, we continue to estimate CapEx of approximately $2 billion, and I'll cover our aircraft CapEx when I review our fleet plans here shortly.
We returned $1.4 billion to our shareholders in 2015, which exceeded our free cash flow of $1.1 billion. And we will have $200 million remaining on the $1.5 billion purchase program as we launch our $500 million accelerated share repurchase, which we will be doing soon. We repaid $213 million in debt and capital lease obligations during 2015 and issued $500 million senior unsecured notes at an all-time low 2.65%. And this was in light of our debt maturities of approximately $600 million here in 2016. 
Our leverage, including off-balance sheet aircraft leases, remains in the low to mid-30% range. And of course, we are very proud of our strong balance sheet with an investment grade rating that was further strengthened during fourth quarter with an upgrade by Fitch to BBB+. And that followed an upgrade in July by Moody's to Baa1. We're focused on preserving the strength of our balance sheet and cash flows while continuing our long-standing track of returning significant value to our shareholders.
I'll move now to our fleet and capacity plans. We ended 2015 with 704 aircraft in our fleet as planned and outlined in this morning's release. Our press release also included our future delivery schedule that I'd point you to that we restructured at the end of December in conjunction with our decision to further accelerate the retirement of our classic fleet. 
I'll quickly take you through the revisions, but they included the conversion of our remaining 25 next-gen -700 firm orders to next-gen -800 firm orders. And it included the addition, as Gary mentioned, of 33 -800 firm deliveries. And as he noted, some of those were options that we had exercised. And we had 2 additional used -700s. We now intend to retire a classic fleet no later than mid-2018, and that's compared to our previous plan that had retirements gearing into 2021. And we had 129 classic aircraft in our fleet at year-end.
Roughly 2/3 of our classic aircraft were impacted by our decision to further accelerate the retirement. The incremental and aircraft in our restructured order book is intended to backfill these aircraft while maintaining our current plans to keep our year-over-year fleet growth over the next 3 years to no more than 2% on average.
The accelerated retirement plan is estimated to produce cumulative EBIT improvement of approximately $200 million over the acceleration period, and that's primarily through maintenance and fuel cost savings. And I'd also note that this incorporates the approximate $100 million in accelerated depreciation that I referred to earlier. 
And the overall customer experience will improve as well with the fully WiFi-equipped more modernized fleet. Our future from capital commitments increased approximately $400 million as a result of the order book revisions. And our 2015 capital expenditures increased $200 million to $300 million, and that was primarily related or that was related to a restructuring of our order book. 
Our aircraft CapEx for 2016 is still estimated to fall in the $1.3 billion to $1.4 billion range. And our average aircraft CapEx for 2017 and 2018 combined is currently estimated to be in a similar range as 2016, which is very manageable.
While the details of our agreement are confidential, the economics of our order book are very supportive of our continued fleet modernization efforts. Overall, the internal rate of return on accelerating retirement of our classic fleet is estimated to exceed our return of investment and this is after-tax, which we reported here in 2015 of almost 21%. So it was a very easy decision for us. We are still optimizing our retirement schedule over the next few years but we expect to end 2016 with roughly 720 aircraft.
With regards to capacity, we ended 2015 as planned and we continue to plan for 5% to 6% year-over-year growth this year. And as we previously noted, the majority of 2016 capacity growth is related to the annualized impact of our 2015 expansion.
So in conclusion, we ended an exceptionally strong 2015 with a record fourth quarter. And our outlook for first quarter calls for another quarter of strong operating margins approaching 20%. Despite a soft yield environment, demand held strong producing a record revenue. We currently estimate our first quarter RASM will be flat year-over-year based on revenue and booking trends thus far in 2016, which suggests a continuation of the strong demand, soft yield environment. 
Substantially lower fuel prices and other cost controls contributed to our favorable cost performance in 2015. And our outlook for 2016 calls for modest cost inflation, excluding fuel, special items and profit sharing. And again, that was driven largely by our decision to accelerate the retirement of our classic fleet, which is expected to produce significant cost savings and an EBIT improvement in the $200 million range. We continue to benefit from lower fuel prices and currently estimate this year's fuel costs to be more than $500 million lower year-over-year based on last Friday's prices and including our current fuel hedge.
Our balance sheet is industry-leading and our cash flows remain strong. And as ever, we are committed to creating value, and we are very pleased that we were able to return over 100% of our free cash flow to shareholders in 2015. 
And as we announced this morning, we will be launching our $500 million accelerated share repurchase soon, which will leave $200 million remaining on our outstanding $1.5 billion buyback authorization. And again, our pretax return on invested capital was an astounding 32.7%. I would like to close by thanking all of our employees for their outstanding contribution to these very strong results.
So with that, Tom, we are ready to take questions.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll now begin with our first question with Jamie Baker with JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll now begin with our first question with Jamie Baker with JPMorgan.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, Jamie. Just out of respect of the process, we'll update that as we progress here.
componenttext: No, Jamie. Just out of respect of the process, we'll update that as we progress here.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, understood. So let me move on to Gary here. Another question on labor. Given your history of profitability, it's no surprise that your 737 wage rates came to represent the peak for U.S. airlines easily over the last decade. But as the competitor wag
componenttext: Sure, understood. So let me move on to Gary here. Another question on labor. Given your history of profitability, it's no surprise that your 737 wage rates came to represent the peak for U.S. airlines easily over the last decade. But as the competitor wage bar beings to rise above yours currently, is it inevitable that Southwest has to establish a new peak with every successful contract? Or put differently, is your business model predicated on maintaining above-market pay scales? Or was that just a by-product poorly competition was at one point?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm going to try to give you -- I'm going to try to answer your question, and I want to try to be diplomatic and respectful of the negotiations process here. But I would just -- I would say our business model, Jamie, is great service and low cost. A
componenttext: Well, I'm going to try to give you -- I'm going to try to answer your question, and I want to try to be diplomatic and respectful of the negotiations process here. But I would just -- I would say our business model, Jamie, is great service and low cost. And we -- every single employee at Southwest Airlines signs up for that. And of course, we all need to continue to work hard everyday to deliver on those 2 things. So that is our business model. Not -- there's never been a promise to be the highest-paying airline in the industry. And so to the extent that we're able to do that because we produce great results, I think that is terrific. But all of that needs to obviously be negotiated with our labor groups, and that's what happens and that's the way that works. I think the overriding objective for us is to continue to have a healthy company, meaning that we're safe and that we're financially strong. And in order to do that, we've got to continue to offer great service and at -- our objective is to be the low-cost producer and live up to the low-fare brand promise that we have.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Excellent. And as a follow-up to that, last point you made, and I guess, this echoes the discussion that you and I had at the Wings Club. You've never faced a larger percentage of competitive capacity that had lower costs than your own than you current do
componenttext: Excellent. And as a follow-up to that, last point you made, and I guess, this echoes the discussion that you and I had at the Wings Club. You've never faced a larger percentage of competitive capacity that had lower costs than your own than you current do. In fact, last time you faced a formidable competitor with a superior cost structure as near as I could tell you, you bought them. So I'm wondering how growth [indiscernible] given their cost structures alters how you think about your own business going forward.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me just affirm virtually everything you said. The only thing I would -- the only edit I would make is that actually when we acquired AirTran, their costs were not lower than ours interestingly enough, at least by my analysis. But clearly, there are ca
componenttext: Let me just affirm virtually everything you said. The only thing I would -- the only edit I would make is that actually when we acquired AirTran, their costs were not lower than ours interestingly enough, at least by my analysis. But clearly, there are carriers today whose costs are lower. On that point, you and I certainly agree. And I -- first of all, I think that it is inevitable that over time, that an industry will get more competitive, especially when there's a disruptor as there has been with Southwest Airlines. So it is not shocking at all that we have more intense competition today than at any time in our history. And it is a challenge for our company and something that I'm very confident that our people will rise up to that challenge. But indeed, it will put an obligation on us to continue to innovate and work very, very hard so that we don't lose our low-fare leadership position in the country. So absolutely, it is different, and I think we recognize that the industry is more competitive today than it has been ever. I would quickly add, by the way, that Southwest has never been stronger. We've never had the route network. We've never had the depth and breadth of the service that we offer. And we've never had a balance sheet this strong. We've never had earnings this strong. So it's really up to us to continue to make sure that we compete and be the best at service and price.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the hedge liability that you called out for '16 and '17, appreciate that detail. I'm just wondering, can that change or is it fully locked in at this point? In other words, if fuel goes higher, does it shrink?
componenttext: So the hedge liability that you called out for '16 and '17, appreciate that detail. I'm just wondering, can that change or is it fully locked in at this point? In other words, if fuel goes higher, does it shrink?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It is -- if fuel goes higher, it certainly starts to shrink so I'll start there. And no, it is not entirely locked in. But I think the main takeaway there is that we will -- as prices go down, so does our fuel bill as well. So yes, I gave you a pretty goo
componenttext: It is -- if fuel goes higher, it certainly starts to shrink so I'll start there. And no, it is not entirely locked in. But I think the main takeaway there is that we will -- as prices go down, so does our fuel bill as well. So yes, I gave you a pretty good amount of detail there on our hedge as I walked through our -- my comments there. So yes, I think we're positioned very well. We know what we have to manage and I think we're positioned well if fuel prices go up or if they go down from here.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then as we think about the capacity that you had in development last year in specifically the Wright Amendment markets, can you help us quantify the benefit you expect having less of that capacity in development? And if you can help us with sor
componenttext: Great. And then as we think about the capacity that you had in development last year in specifically the Wright Amendment markets, can you help us quantify the benefit you expect having less of that capacity in development? And if you can help us with sort of the full pie, maybe could just talk about the market that you launched in late 2014 that you should have had basically a year of experience with by the fourth quarter if you saw sort of significant RASM improvement there.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Duane, you were fading in and out but I think we got the gist of your question. Yes, we have -- we can quantify, at least from an internal perspective, what we think the opportunity is there. I would just start out by acknowledging that, that assumes all
componenttext: Duane, you were fading in and out but I think we got the gist of your question. Yes, we have -- we can quantify, at least from an internal perspective, what we think the opportunity is there. I would just start out by acknowledging that, that assumes all else is equal. And I'm sure that you and everyone else understand that but Tammy,

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, just a couple of comments there to maybe help you out, Duane. We had, again like you said, a high number -- high percentage of our markets were under development. You know what those markets are. And I'll remind you that the high percentages did incl
componenttext: Yes, just a couple of comments there to maybe help you out, Duane. We had, again like you said, a high number -- high percentage of our markets were under development. You know what those markets are. And I'll remind you that the high percentages did include the market that we were converting from AirTran over to Southwest. So point I'm making there is not all of the markets are created equal. Obviously, we reported a lot on Dallas Love Field and are very pleased with how those markets are progressing. But we wouldn't expect our international markets, as an example, to mature as a right we would say at Dallas or even the AirTran market. So they're all a little bit different, but I can at least help quantify the impact we're expecting here in the first quarter. And if you -- it's probably in terms of -- it's probably a 1-point, I'll call it, maybe not even a 1-point impact from development markets. So as we move into 2016, at least my expectation would be that we'll get some tailwinds from our development markets as those continue to mature.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Rajeev Lalwani with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Rajeev Lalwani with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 for you, guys. The first, I guess, with oil coming down so much and obviously, you're going to see that benefit from the fuel numbers you provided, how does that impact how you're thinking about the business either from a revenue or a capacity stan
componenttext: Just 2 for you, guys. The first, I guess, with oil coming down so much and obviously, you're going to see that benefit from the fuel numbers you provided, how does that impact how you're thinking about the business either from a revenue or a capacity standpoint, if at all? And then second question was just, you announced the aircraft order today and the acceleration. What drove that? What changed over the last couple of months? It seems like that opportunity has been out there for some time.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tammy, I'll take a shot and if you want to chime in, please do on both of those. The -- I would admit to you all that it is -- the year is off to a very concerning start when it comes to headlines around the world. It's almost as if we're living in a diff
componenttext: Tammy, I'll take a shot and if you want to chime in, please do on both of those. The -- I would admit to you all that it is -- the year is off to a very concerning start when it comes to headlines around the world. It's almost as if we're living in a different dimension here at Southwest and from what I've heard from some of our competitor reports too. So our business continues to be strong, but I will quickly admit that there are concerning headlines around the world. So you translate this to oil prices and living in Texas my entire life, this is an oil and gas state. And yes, it is concerning the impact that it will have on companies and debt payments and jobs and so on. There's no question that the United States has benefited from the oil and gas boom that was occurring over the last x number of years since the -- really since the recession. So yes, that's all a concern that no doubt you have, we share that. But at least in terms of seeing any manifestation of that in our business, we just -- we don't see it. Even our oil and gas markets, if you want to call them that, produced very strong results in the fourth quarter. Several of our markets have year-over-year yield pressure, if you will, so that's not unique to those markets, but they still produced very, very handsome returns. But yes, it's just something we're going to have to keep our eye on. And I offer that background just as an acknowledgment that we're just living in a world where we need to continue to be alert and be cautious. I will then follow on and say that we felt like our plan for 2015 was sound and it turned out to be so. We think that the follow-on plan here for 2016 is also sound. It is more conservative than what we had committed ourselves to for last year. And as Tammy and I have both reiterated, we've not made any change with our capacity outlook and especially for 2016. We're still right in the 5% to 6% range. And I think all of us would be prepared that if, for whatever reason, travel demand weakens, then we would be -- we would want to address that and then at least discuss what kind of options we have to react on the downside. But in terms of taking advantage -- further advantage of low energy prices and boosting our capacity, we don't have any plans to do that. So Tammy, before we go on to the second question, anything you would like to add?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think that was perfect, yes. And in terms of the -- your question on why did we decide to accelerate the classics. I guess, I'll just point back to our fleet modernization efforts that when we set our plan, I guess I just have to say we've been very
componenttext: No, I think that was perfect, yes. And in terms of the -- your question on why did we decide to accelerate the classics. I guess, I'll just point back to our fleet modernization efforts that when we set our plan, I guess I just have to say we've been very pleased with the benefits from our fleet modernizations so far. And as we continued to evaluate just the operating cost of operating classic as the windows and size we just really took out our pencils, evaluated it and we were able to come up with a plan that actually is going to enable us to improve our EBIT with very -- at very modest capital levels. So I think you know Southwest well. We prefer a simplified fleet. And even the classics fleet of 737, we'd much prefer to operate 700s and 800s, and it certainly simplifies a lot of the operations and also just improves the reliability in terms of just less downtime from a maintenance perspective. So I think we'll get -- also get a boost from the productivity of our fleet, which certainly was part of the EBIT contribution that we're expecting. So all in all, when we sat down and evaluated it, it became pretty compelling to go ahead and accelerate the classics. So hopefully, that helps provide a little color as to what went into the decision-making process. Gary, did you have anything?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tammy, the only thing I would say about -- it's always a fair question. Why now? Why not earlier? Why not later? And I think it's back to that convergence or confluence of things. First of all, we're at a fleet number that is manageable to think about acc
componenttext: Tammy, the only thing I would say about -- it's always a fair question. Why now? Why not earlier? Why not later? And I think it's back to that convergence or confluence of things. First of all, we're at a fleet number that is manageable to think about accelerating retirement in that way. We have more out-of-service time with those airplanes for maintenance reasons than we do the rest of our fleet. So -- and Tammy made that point I just want to reiterate. You'll get a lot more productivity out of a new airplane than what we are currently getting out of these classics, which means you don't necessarily even have to have a tail-by-tail replacement, although that is our plan. But they'll be more efficient. The other thing is that Boeing was available to us. Boeing had delivery positions. And we were able to strike a deal with them in a way that was -- that worked for them and was a win for them, it was a win for us. So that was key. With respect to our people, I think about the people after touch the airplane, the pilots, flight attendants, mechanics, especially. It's just far easier for our people to operate the next-gen than it is the classics. That's just a fact. So this will simplify a lot of things for all 3 of those workgroups, and in particular, our pilots. So it's a good deal. It works out -- it'd be better for our customers. And all the way around, we're just delighted that we have this alternative available, and we were able to pull it all together at the end of the year. But it was an idea and a decision that was aggressively pursued in 2015, in fact, the latter part of 2015 and fortunately, it all came together.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just again on the cost. Obviously, as always, it's just part of our DNA at Southwest. We're very focused on cost and being the low-cost producer and this is just yet another way to help us as we're managing our costs here over the next several years.
componenttext: And just again on the cost. Obviously, as always, it's just part of our DNA at Southwest. We're very focused on cost and being the low-cost producer and this is just yet another way to help us as we're managing our costs here over the next several years.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Hunter Keay with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Hunter Keay with Wolfe Research.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: You guys didn't buy back stock in the quarter for the first time in almost 5 years. Looks like you still have some money left in the repo and I understand you did the $500 million ARS. But I would have thought you guys would have come in and bought some a
componenttext: You guys didn't buy back stock in the quarter for the first time in almost 5 years. Looks like you still have some money left in the repo and I understand you did the $500 million ARS. But I would have thought you guys would have come in and bought some after cutting the revenue guide. Did that have anything to do -- not buying the stock, have anything to do with posting $800-some-odd million of hedge collateral? Or can you give us any kind of color as to thinking behind sort of putting it on hold for the quarter?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, Hunter, it didn't have anything to do with the fuel hedge collateral and honestly wouldn't read anything into that at all. We are more focused, as we said this morning, we're launching a $500 million accelerated share repurchase. And so we're -- we'll
componenttext: No, Hunter, it didn't have anything to do with the fuel hedge collateral and honestly wouldn't read anything into that at all. We are more focused, as we said this morning, we're launching a $500 million accelerated share repurchase. And so we're -- we'll get that launched soon, and then after that, we will have $200 million remaining on our $1.5 billion, which was approved at our shareholder meeting last May. So we've gone through that authorization pretty darn quick, returning more than 100% of our free cash flow in 2014 to our shareholders. So very proud of what we did there in 2014 with respect to share repurchases. So again when -- actually, that included our dividend. So very -- so we are -- I don't think there's any anything larger than that.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That was already a record amount. And as we've allowed here, we were also beginning to have serious thoughts and conversations with Boeing Company and what -- how that cash flow might flow from that deal. So -- but I think what's material is that we've an
componenttext: That was already a record amount. And as we've allowed here, we were also beginning to have serious thoughts and conversations with Boeing Company and what -- how that cash flow might flow from that deal. So -- but I think what's material is that we've announced the $500 million today.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, okay, that's fair. And it looks like when I look at schedule data, it looks like you guys are trimming a little bit of capacity out of Love Field market into LaGuardia and Reagan and moving some of that out west a little bit. Does that have anything
componenttext: Yes, okay, that's fair. And it looks like when I look at schedule data, it looks like you guys are trimming a little bit of capacity out of Love Field market into LaGuardia and Reagan and moving some of that out west a little bit. Does that have anything to do with the operational challenges that you might be encountering at Love Field because of the ongoing legal dispute? And obviously, the ruling didn't go your way and you're going to appeal it. But does that have anything to do with that or is that unrelated and really there's other factors sort of like market demand-based decisions? Any color around sort of what's going into that correct.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, you bet. Yes, sir, you bet. No, there's no -- I think our operations folks have done a marvelous job. They're doing what is for us 10 turns a day on a gate with -- and less than full utilization of 18 gates. So the operation actually is doing fine, w
componenttext: Yes, you bet. Yes, sir, you bet. No, there's no -- I think our operations folks have done a marvelous job. They're doing what is for us 10 turns a day on a gate with -- and less than full utilization of 18 gates. So the operation actually is doing fine, which simply means that we have -- when we finally get access to all of the gates, we'll be able to put more flights in there. But you'll note, Hunter, that we make changes all over the country, and we don't make dramatic changes in Dallas, but you've got markets like Seattle that come to mind and Fort Myers, Florida where we make very significant seasonal adjustments. The other thing that I mentioned to the media on this very same question this morning is that with -- you know that we have a lot of new flying that's transpired since October 2014. And I went through all that stuff and so has Tammy. So with all of those new routes, I think we would readily admit to you that in some cases, we may not -- we may have too many flights in some places, we may not have enough flights in places, and so there's always some tuning that continues. And that is all that's going on here at Love Field. So my recollection, we're still at 180 daily departures would probably cut through everything. And answers your question best that way. But yes, we've got some pluses and minuses and routes and there's nothing unusual about that.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Savi Syth with Raymond James.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Savi Syth with Raymond James.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the unit cost growth. I was just kind of curious with the higher capacity growth in the first half, I would have thought maybe a little surprised at the 2% [ph] CASM growth. And I'm just wondering, I know the 1 point from the accelerated depreciat
componenttext: Just on the unit cost growth. I was just kind of curious with the higher capacity growth in the first half, I would have thought maybe a little surprised at the 2% [ph] CASM growth. And I'm just wondering, I know the 1 point from the accelerated depreciation. Just wondering timing cost timing issues or what was leading to that slightly higher increase in 1Q?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, you're exactly right, Savi. The guidance for the full year is 1%. So you're exactly right. It's just a timing of when our expenses are falling.
componenttext: Yes, you're exactly right, Savi. The guidance for the full year is 1%. So you're exactly right. It's just a timing of when our expenses are falling.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then another just -- just on the ULCC question as they came up before. Just wondering Gary, maybe if you have any thoughts here. It seems like the industry was going through a bit of a segmentation. And I know Southwest wants to be kind of the
componenttext: Got it. And then another just -- just on the ULCC question as they came up before. Just wondering Gary, maybe if you have any thoughts here. It seems like the industry was going through a bit of a segmentation. And I know Southwest wants to be kind of the leading low-cost low-fare airline. But there is a product differential and then be it your kind of on-time performance or be it the products, the service, a myriad of things. So I was just kind of curious as to what your thought process is. Do you need to be the lowest fare, recognizing that there is a difference in product? And then maybe your thoughts on kind of the customer segmentation if there is a customer segmentation? Or if it's -- if this a truly like a commodity business and then you just have to be have the lowest fares?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I love your question. I love everybody's question, but that, I think that's one that's an interesting one to share, and I'm happy to have an opportunity to address it. We want to be the best service at the lowest price, period. And in describing pri
componenttext: Well, I love your question. I love everybody's question, but that, I think that's one that's an interesting one to share, and I'm happy to have an opportunity to address it. We want to be the best service at the lowest price, period. And in describing price, I would agree that we're going to have to do some comparisons between unbundled pricing versus our more bundled approach. All-in, I want Southwest Airlines to be lowest price. We'll win if we have the best service at the lowest price. And that's been our tradition. That's been our history. That's what the whole company is based upon. And that's what our growth plans are fundamentally based upon. I think it is a slippery slope to accept that our cost and our fares can be higher based on service, because as you well know, there's a long list of failures in the airline industry who pursue that exact strategic plan. And it's really a cop-out. It's really not facing up to the challenges of finding more and better ways to compete on cost and on price. So the thing I love about Southwest is it's been a company who's been able to do both. And the other thing that you find, I think, is, which is a slippery slope is companies can change. And while service may not be a great attribute for some of our competitors today who will go [indiscernible] who's to say they can't change in that in the future? And so we need to continue to strive to be the best at both, and we need -- while we may not have all the answers in any given point in time, I think that, that needs to continue to be our guiding light.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we have time for one more question. We'll take our last question from Michael Linenberg with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And we have time for one more question. We'll take our last question from Michael Linenberg with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: 2 quick ones here. When we started the quarter, the guide was for RASM to be up about 1%. And as we moved through much of the quarter, that number was out there. And then I don't know, about a month back, you took guidance down. And when I think about acr
componenttext: 2 quick ones here. When we started the quarter, the guide was for RASM to be up about 1%. And as we moved through much of the quarter, that number was out there. And then I don't know, about a month back, you took guidance down. And when I think about across the industry, we did see some of the carriers come in with weaker-than-expected unit revenues. Some of it was fuel surcharges, some of it was FX. Some of it was the Paris attacks. Those are the types of things that I didn't think impacted you on one hand. Then on the other, we did hear that some airlines just ran a better operation because the winter weather wasn't that bad. So I'm curious with your exposure in the energy patch, I mean, was that some of it that you saw some demand weakness in your core energy markets? Or is it just a better run operation? I mean, what drove that down so much?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, I don't think Tammy would either. I wouldn't blame our energy markets at all. Although as I mentioned earlier, I think it is true that the energy markets are seeing some softness in RASM year-over-year but it's still really healthy. I think the thin
componenttext: Mike, I don't think Tammy would either. I wouldn't blame our energy markets at all. Although as I mentioned earlier, I think it is true that the energy markets are seeing some softness in RASM year-over-year but it's still really healthy. I think the thing that's -- and Tammy will have better insights, no doubt, but the thing that stands out to me was Thanksgiving. And we were pretty much tracking along with our forecast for the quarter until then. And it was all -- if you'll recall our discussion with our November traffic, the pricing environment was not -- it was -- I used the word it was quoted at the time, it was unusual. So the Christmas holiday period was more normal. But regardless, you kind of fast forward now, and Tammy, maybe you -- maybe it might be more helpful to talk about current trends as opposed to what changed but that -- Mike, that was the main thing that I recall in the fourth quarter was the yields over the week of Thanksgiving holiday travel based on unusual discounting in the industry were lower than what we would have predicted. But anything you want to add there, Tammy?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Gary, I agree. That really was what was -- that was primarily what was different from what our forecast was going into the quarter. But we ended the year with the holiday performance in December. That was actually within our expectations. So as we're
componenttext: Yes, Gary, I agree. That really was what was -- that was primarily what was different from what our forecast was going into the quarter. But we ended the year with the holiday performance in December. That was actually within our expectations. So as we're just trying to sort through all of that, I would just -- our expectation going into the first quarter based on what we've seen so far in January is demand seems strong. We're continuing to see strong load factors. But again, we're also continuing to see those come in at weaker yields. So that -- so at least, I guess the way I would characterize it at least from what we're seeing so far in our bookings is stabilized.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, the only other thing I would just point out is we had the same question here after -- so Thanksgiving occurred after the Paris attacks. And whether there was a -- an effect on bookings with us, with our competitor, I don't know. That's hard to tease
componenttext:
Mike, the only other thing I would just point out is we had the same question here after -- so Thanksgiving occurred after the Paris attacks. And whether there was a -- an effect on bookings with us, with our competitor, I don't know. That's hard to tease out, if all that. But the other thing that's going on is you look at the broader GDP results for the fourth quarter, and they weren't very good. So it's possible that the industry was seeing some softening in demand that led to more aggressive discounting. And it's, coupled with the industry also growing faster than GDP. So it wouldn't be shocking to find that there was a little bit of a rough patch there and just trying to get supply and demand cleared. If [indiscernible] by price. But in any event, beyond that, we're continuing to manage our developing markets. We're continuing to manage our markets in which there are competitive changes in terms of pluses and minuses and activity. And overall, the demand, as we said, demand it all adds up to.
[Audio Gap]

componenttext: I think, Tammy, you gave the full year number, 5% to 6%, which is obviously unchanged. Do you have kind of rough -- what those rates are by quarter, how we should model it for the year?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Has Southwest recently exited any fuel hedge contracts early for the participation in fuel price decline? And if so, at what cost?
componenttext: Has Southwest recently exited any fuel hedge contracts early for the participation in fuel price decline? And if so, at what cost?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll be happy to take that. We have reduced our hedges here in 2016. So the answer to that question would be yes. We -- I guess, just looking at what we had last reported to you in terms of our hedge percentages, I guess the main difference would be
componenttext: Yes, I'll be happy to take that. We have reduced our hedges here in 2016. So the answer to that question would be yes. We -- I guess, just looking at what we had last reported to you in terms of our hedge percentages, I guess the main difference would be in the second half of 2016. So we did reduce our hedges there substantially in light of the declining fuel markets. So we went from, call it, 60% to 70% in the second half of 2016 to probably closer to 30% to 35%.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And a brief follow-up to make sure I understood your earlier comments correctly. Is Southwest relying more heavily on call options this year than last?
componenttext: Great. And a brief follow-up to make sure I understood your earlier comments correctly. Is Southwest relying more heavily on call options this year than last?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That would be going forward and that's correct. And in fact, our 2018 position is only -- only represents call option. And that's exactly right.
componenttext: That would be going forward and that's correct. And in fact, our 2018 position is only -- only represents call option. And that's exactly right.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in other words, what we were already long with a position for '16 and '17 as 2015 unfolded. So Tammy and her team are continuing to work those positions off as best they can. But then any additional hedges that they're doing, they're doing with the cal
componenttext: So in other words, what we were already long with a position for '16 and '17 as 2015 unfolded. So Tammy and her team are continuing to work those positions off as best they can. But then any additional hedges that they're doing, they're doing with the call options to answer your question there.
