headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to today's call to discuss our fourth quarter 2015 results. Joining me on the call today, we have Gary Kelly, Chairman, President and CEO; Tammy Romo, Executive Vice President and CFO; Bob Jordan, Ex
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to today's call to discuss our fourth quarter 2015 results. Joining me on the call today, we have Gary Kelly, Chairman, President and CEO; Tammy Romo, Executive Vice President and CFO; Bob Jordan, Executive Vice President and Chief Commercial Officer; Mike Van De Ven, Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer.
Please note today's call will include forward-looking statements, and because these statements are based on the company's current intent, expectations and projections, they are not guarantees of future performance and a variety of factors could cause actual results to differ materially. As this call will include references to non-GAAP results excluding special items, please refer to this morning's press release in the Investor Relations section of southwest.com for further information regarding forward-looking statements and reconciliations of non-GAAP results to GAAP results.
At this time, I'd like to go ahead and turn the call over to Gary for opening remarks.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Marcy, and thanks, everybody, for joining us today for our year-end 2015 earnings call. This was another superb and critical year for Southwest, and I am very grateful to all of our people for their hard work. I want to especially thank them fo
componenttext:
Thank you, Marcy, and thanks, everybody, for joining us today for our year-end 2015 earnings call. This was another superb and critical year for Southwest, and I am very grateful to all of our people for their hard work. I want to especially thank them for these terrific results. 
Tammy is going to take us through the quarter, but I want to offer up not a comprehensive overview, but at least a few highlights. Of course, this was, by far, our best year of earnings in our entire history and that includes a record return on invested capital of 32.7%. We no doubt benefited from 29% lower economic jet fuel prices. Obviously, that was a major component of our earnings, but so were record load factors and our revenues were up also a very solid 5.6%. 
It was a strategic year for us in that we had secular growth opportunities out of Dallas arising from the repeal of the Wright Amendment and of course that has been a phenomenal success. We've also had secular growth opportunities out of Washington Reagan and LaGuardia that is arising from the acquisition of slots. It was also a year that followed the -- at the end of 2014, the completion of the AirTran acquisition and integration. A lot of new markets resulted from that. And then, of course, it was also a year where we had a unique opportunity in which to build an international terminal and launch international flights out of Houston Hobby. That was for the first time since 1969, by the way. All of that added up to capacity growth of 7.2%, and then of course, we were delighted that traffic was stronger than that, it grew 8.8%. 
And as a backdrop, the economy for last year was solid. Travel demand was solid, and of course, energy prices moved even lower. So the convergence of all of these things made 2015 a very successful year, but again, one that was also very strategic for us.  And we accomplished virtually everything that we've set out to do. In some cases where we didn't, we at least made significant progress. I'm very happy about that, but certainly that includes generating record operating cash flow, strong free cash flow and we also returned a record $1.4 billion to shareholders in the form of share repurchases and dividends. 
So I want to make sure that I highlight 2 announcements from this morning's release. First of all, we announced that we will soon launch a $500 million accelerated share repurchase program, I'm sure you all saw that. And then second, we recently ordered 33 new 737-800s from Boeing and that is spread out for delivery in '16, '17 and '18. And the sole purpose for that is to accelerate further the retirement of our classic fleet. So mechanically, we did that by exercising 6 options and then on top of that we placed new orders for 27 more. So you get to 33 more new airplanes. And then in addition to that, on our fleet chart, you'll also see that we have committed to 2 more used aircraft. But I just want to reiterate that our capacity plans for the next 5 years are essentially unchanged by this announcement. We're replacing the classics with next-generation airplanes. And then, in particular, our capacity plans for 2016 are unchanged, and we still plan to grow this year between 5% and 6%. So the financial, operations and customer service effects of this fleet announcement are all very favorable, and Tammy will take us through all that.
Work continues along 3 basic themes this year as far as investment goes for the future. One is we have significant airport renovation and infrastructure projects underway across the country. Some we're managing, some we're not, but a big project in LAX, Fort Lauderdale, Chicago Midway and New Orleans and that Fort Lauderdale, in particular, will bring on new capacity for us in 2017. Number two, we've got a significant commercial technology program underway. And the headline on that, of course, is the replacement of our reservation system and that's also targeted for 2017. And then, finally, we have a major program underway with our operations technology. And the headline on that is the new 737 MAX, along with other very significant technology improvements that Mike Van De Ven has planned and that is also a 2017 deliverable, at least with respect to the MAX. 
So for this year, in addition to our focus on these investment programs, we want to do a handful of things. We want to continue to manage our network growth and mature our developing markets; number two, we want to compete vigorously in an increasingly competitive environment; number three, we want to continue to work on and improve our reliability of our operations; next, we want to continue our focus on the hospitality of our customer service, and through all of this, we want to continue to grow our unit revenues, our margins and our earnings. So there's nothing really fancy about that or 2016, pretty basic blocking and tackling things, but clearly 2017 is shaping up to be a pretty big year for Southwest Airlines.
I just want to highlight for our Southwest people finally that our profit sharing for 2015 will eclipse last year's record and increase by 74% to an all-time record of $620 million, and I'm very pleased about that. I'm very proud of them and their hard work. And I am very pleased that they're being justly rewarded with that. 
So Tammy, with that quick overview, I'd love to turn it over to you and have you take us through the quarter.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, thank you, Gary, and welcome, everyone. We are very pleased to report a banner year of record performance in 2015, representing our 43rd consecutive year of profits. Our annual earnings, excluding special items, were a record $2.4 billion or $3
componenttext:
All right, thank you, Gary, and welcome, everyone. We are very pleased to report a banner year of record performance in 2015, representing our 43rd consecutive year of profits. Our annual earnings, excluding special items, were a record $2.4 billion or $3.52 per diluted share, which was an increase of 75% year-over-year. 
Our fourth quarter performance was also record-setting, representing -- represented our 11th consecutive quarter of profit. Fourth quarter net income, excluding special items, increased 46% year-over-year to $591 million or $0.90 per share, which was in line with consensus.  Operating income, excluding special items, was a record $992 million, which produced a 5-point improvement in operating margin of 19.9%, which is the best fourth quarter margin performance we've seen since 1978. And it's also worth noting like last quarter, with or without the benefit of substantially lower fuel prices, our earnings and margins improved year-over-year. And the record that really stands out is our pretax return on invested capital, excluding special items, of 32.7%.  I'd like to congratulate all of our outstanding employees on these fantastic results. And like Gary, I'm thrilled we can reward our employees with a record-breaking profit sharing of $620 million for 2015. 
Our total operating revenues in fourth quarter were a record $5 billion, up 7.5% year-over-year on a capacity increase of 8.4%. Passenger revenues were also a record $4.6 billion.  Demand for our low fares remained very strong throughout the quarter, resulting in more than 11% growth in traffic and an all-time fourth quarter high -- record-high load factor. A softer yield environment resulted in a 7% decline in passenger revenue yields and an $8 decrease in our average fare. Our fourth quarter operating revenues included a $125 million net benefit from the amended Chase contract and the required accounting treatment. And this $125 million benefit was about a 2- to 3-point improvement to RASM.
For 2016, we expect to realize a year-over-year incremental benefit from the amended Chase agreement and accounting change. But once we reach third quarter, we will, of course, lapse the year-over-year benefit. For first quarter 2016, our estimated incremental benefit is approximately $110 million and that is included in the RASM guidance that we provided.  Our developmental markets continue to perform in line with our expectations. And Dallas continues to outperform the system on margins and returns.
International is also developing as planned including our inaugural service from Houston, which was launched during the fourth quarter. Our fourth quarter RASM declined 0.7%, which was in line with our guidance. Considering a point impact from development markets and roughly 2-point impact from increased gauge and stage, we're very pleased with our fourth quarter record, and likely, industry-leading revenue performance.
Thus far, in January, demand for our low fares remains strong. Soft yet stable yields have continued thus far into first quarter. And based on our current bookings and revenue trends, we are estimating first quarter 2016 RASM will be flat year-over-year. In light of the current yield environment, we're very pleased with our first quarter revenue outlook at this juncture. Our freight and other revenue production was also favorable. In addition to the incremental benefit from the amended Chase card that I mentioned earlier, our ancillary revenue production was strong, led by growth in EarlyBird and our upgraded boarding revenues. And we currently expect first quarter 2016 freight and other revenues to be comparable with fourth quarter 2015.
I'll turn to our cost performance now. And our fourth quarter unit cost, excluding special items, decreased just under 7% year-over-year due to substantially lower fuel prices and cost control, particularly our fleet modernization effort. Our economic fuel costs decreased almost $200 million year-over-year and that was driven by the 23% decline in fuel prices. With the current state of the oil market and oversupply situation, we currently expect another year-over-year decline in first quarter and full year 2016 economic fuel costs.
Based on our current hedge portfolio for this year and market prices as of last Friday, we expect our first quarter fuel price to be approximately $1.70 per gallon, and I'll also provide you our estimates by quarter here. Second quarter is expected to be approximately $1.60 per gallon. And second half, we expect that to be in the $1.80 to $1.95 per gallon range again based on last Friday. And that brings us to a full year 2016 fuel price per gallon in the $1.70 to $1.75 range. So while above market prices, we're still benefiting from lower fuel prices and currently estimate over $500 million in economic fuel savings this year. Our first quarter 2016 estimated fuel price per gallon is below last year's $2 per gallon and represents the lowest economic fuel price we've realized since third quarter of 2006. 
With respect to our hedge book. Our strong profit margins today call for a more conservative approach to hedging in this environment -- in this low fuel environment. We will continue to manage our existing portfolio to minimize costs as we burn off our 2016 and 2017 positions. Prospectively, we'll focus on catastrophic protection with no downside risk, particularly in this environment. For 2018, as we reported, we are 35% hedged and that's with all calls and call spreads. So while our hedging philosophy has not changed, our tactics have in this environment. And we will manage through our portfolio, and this -- since fourth quarter of 2015, we participated in 85% of the market decline.
So I'll take you through our nonfuel costs quickly. Excluding fuel and special items, our unit costs were flat, including a 30% year-over-year increase in profit sharing that our employees earned for fourth quarter 2015. Profit sharing expense accrued in the fourth quarter was $136 million and that brings again the total for the year to an astounding $620 million, which, again, was 75% year-over-year. Excluding profit sharing and special items, our nonfuel unit costs decreased 1.1% year-over-year, which was towards the more favorable end of our cost guidance due primarily to a reduction in advertise spend and lower airport costs than we had expected. Our fleet modernization produced the expected $700 million in EBIT this year and that's even with the drop in fuel prices. 
So based on our current cost trends, we expect first quarter 2016 CASM, excluding fuel, special items and profit sharing, to increase approximately 2% year-over-year. And keep in mind that roughly 1 point of the year-over-year increase is driven by accelerated depreciation, which, of course, is a noncash charge from our recent decision to accelerate the retirement of the classic fleet that Gary took you through. For our full year 2016, we are currently estimating a 1% year-over-year increase in our unit costs, excluding fuel, special items and profit sharing. And again, this modest cost inflation is almost entirely driven by the accelerated depreciation.  And as a quick reminder, as we noted in our press release this morning, this cost guidance only reflects current labor contracts. Therefore, it does not include the impact from the tentative agreement currently out for vote with our ramp, operations, provisioning and cargo vote.
I'll move to our balance sheet and cash flow. And of course, our balance sheet and cash flows remained very strong. We ended the quarter with $3.1 billion in cash and short-term investments and that's after posting $835 million in cash collateral to third parties. We generated $3.2 billion in operating cash flow in 2015 and incurred $2 billion in capital expenditures. For 2016, we continue to estimate CapEx of approximately $2 billion, and I'll cover our aircraft CapEx when I review our fleet plans here shortly.
We returned $1.4 billion to our shareholders in 2015, which exceeded our free cash flow of $1.1 billion. And we will have $200 million remaining on the $1.5 billion purchase program after we launch our $500 million accelerated share repurchase, which we will be doing soon. We repaid $213 million in debt and capital lease obligations during 2015 and issued $500 million senior unsecured notes at an all-time low 2.65%. And this was in light of our debt maturities of approximately $600 million here in 2016. 
Our leverage including off-balance sheet aircraft leases remains in the low to mid-30% range. And of course, we are very proud of our strong balance sheet with an investment grade rating that was further strengthened during fourth quarter with an upgrade by Fitch to BBB+ and that followed an upgrade in July by Moody's to Baa1. We're focused on preserving the strength of our balance sheet and cash flows while continuing our long-standing track of returning significant value to our shareholders.
I'll move now to our fleet and capacity plans. We ended 2015 with 704 aircraft in our fleet, as planned and outlined in this morning's release. Our press release also included our future delivery schedule that I'd point you to that we restructured at the end of December in conjunction with our decision to further accelerate the retirement of our classic fleet. 
I'll quickly take you through the revisions, that they included the conversion of our remaining 25 next-gen -700 firm orders to next-gen -800 firm orders and it included the addition, as Gary mentioned, of 33 -800 firm deliveries. And as he noted, some of those were options that we had exercised. And we had 2 additional used -700s. We now intend to retire our classic fleet no later than mid-2018 and that's compared to our previous plan that had retirements carrying into 2021. And we had 129 classic aircraft in our fleet at year-end.
Roughly 2/3 of our classic aircraft were impacted by our decision to further accelerate the retirement. And the incremental seat gauge and aircraft in our restructured order book is intended to backfill these aircraft while maintaining our current plans to keep our year-over-year fleet growth over the next 3 years to no more than 2% on average. The accelerated retirement plan is estimated to produce cumulative EBIT improvement of approximately $200 million over the acceleration period and that's primarily through maintenance and fuel cost savings. And I'd also note that this incorporates the approximate $100 million in accelerated depreciation that I referred to earlier. And the overall customer experience will improve as well with the fully WiFi-equipped, more modernized fleet. 
Our future firm capital commitments increased approximately $400 million as a result of the order book revisions. And our 2015 capital expenditures increased $200 million to $300 million and that was primarily related -- or that was related to the restructuring of our order book. Our aircraft CapEx for 2016 is still estimated to fall in the $1.3 billion to $1.4 billion range. And our average aircraft CapEx for 2017 and 2018 combined is currently estimated to be in a similar range as 2016, which is very manageable. While the details of our Boeing agreement are confidential, the economics of our NG order book are very supportive of our continued fleet modernization effort. 
Overall, the internal rate of return on accelerating the retirement of our classic fleet is estimated to exceed our -- the return of investment, and this is after-tax, which we reported here in 2015 of almost 21% so it was a very easy decision for us. We are still optimizing our retirement schedule over the next few years, but we expect to end 2016 with roughly 720 aircraft. With regards to capacity, we ended 2015 as planned and we continue to plan for 5% to 6% year-over-year growth this year. And as we previously noted, the majority of 2016's capacity growth is related to the annualized impact of our 2015 expansion.
So in conclusion. We ended an exceptionally strong 2015 with a record fourth quarter, and our outlook for first quarter calls for another quarter of strong operating margins approaching 20%. Despite a soft yield environment, demand held strong producing record revenues. We currently estimate our first quarter RASM will be flat year-over-year based on revenue and booking trends thus far in 2016, which suggest a continuation of the strong-demand, soft-yield environment. 
Substantially lower fuel prices and other cost controls contributed to our favorable cost performance in 2015. And our outlook for 2016 calls for modest cost inflation, excluding fuel, special items and profit sharing and again that was driven largely by our decision to accelerate the retirement of our classic fleet, which is expected to produce significant cost savings and an EBIT improvement in the $200 million range. We continue to benefit from lower fuel prices and currently estimate this year's fuel costs to be more than $500 million lower year-over-year based on last Friday's prices and including our current fuel hedge.
Our balance sheet is industry-leading and our cash flows remain strong. And as ever, we are committed to creating value, and we are very pleased that we were able to return over 100% of our free cash flow to shareholders in 2015. And as we announced this morning, we will be launching our $500 million accelerated share repurchase soon, which will leave $200 million remaining on our outstanding $1.5 billion buyback authorization. And again, our pretax return on invested capital was an astounding 32.7%.  I would like to close by thanking all of our employees for their outstanding contribution to these very strong results.
So with that, Tom, we are ready to take questions.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll now begin with our first question from Jamie Baker with JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll now begin with our first question from Jamie Baker with JPMorgan.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hoping to ask 2.5 questions here. The half question, Tammy, United also has a TA -- 2 TAs out right now. They guided this morning on the impact, assuming ratification. Are you willing to do the same in terms of what that would mean for the ex fuel CASM gu
componenttext: Hoping to ask 2.5 questions here. The half question, Tammy, United also has a TA -- 2 TAs out right now. They guided this morning on the impact, assuming ratification. Are you willing to do the same in terms of what that would mean for the ex fuel CASM guide you just gave?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, Jamie. Just out of respect of the process, we'll update that as we progress here.
componenttext: No, Jamie. Just out of respect of the process, we'll update that as we progress here.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, understood. So let me move onto Gary here and another question on labor. Given your history of profitability, it's no surprise that your 737 wage rates came to represent the peak for U.S. airlines easily over the last decade. But as the competitor w
componenttext: Sure, understood. So let me move onto Gary here and another question on labor. Given your history of profitability, it's no surprise that your 737 wage rates came to represent the peak for U.S. airlines easily over the last decade. But as the competitor wage bar begins to rise above yours currently, is it inevitable that Southwest has to establish a new peak with every successful contract? Or put differently, is your business model predicated on maintaining above-market pay scales? Or was that just a by-product of how poorly the competition was at one point?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm going to try to give you a -- I'm going to try to answer your question and I want to try to be diplomatic and respectful of the negotiations process here. But I would just -- I would say our business model, Jamie, is great service and low costs.
componenttext: Well, I'm going to try to give you a -- I'm going to try to answer your question and I want to try to be diplomatic and respectful of the negotiations process here. But I would just -- I would say our business model, Jamie, is great service and low costs. And we -- every single employee at Southwest Airlines signs up for that and of course we all need to continue to work hard every day to deliver on those 2 things. So that is our business model. Not -- there's never been a promise to be the highest-paying airline in the industry. And so to the extent that we're able to do that because we produce great results, I think that is terrific. But all of that needs to obviously be negotiated with our labor groups and that's what happens and that's the way that works. But I think the overriding objective for us is to continue to have a healthy company, meaning that we're safe and that we're financially strong. And in order to do that, we've got to continue to offer great service and at -- our objective is to be the low-cost producer and live up to the low-fare brand promise that we have.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Excellent. And as a follow-up to that last point you made and I guess this echoes the discussion that you and I had at the Wings Club, you've never faced a larger percentage of competitive capacity that had lower costs than your own, than you currently do
componenttext: Excellent. And as a follow-up to that last point you made and I guess this echoes the discussion that you and I had at the Wings Club, you've never faced a larger percentage of competitive capacity that had lower costs than your own, than you currently do. In fact, last time you faced a formidable competitor with a superior cost structure, as near as I could tell, you bought them. So I'm wondering how growth at Spirit and Frontier, given their cost structures, alters how you think about your own business going forward.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and let me just affirm virtually everything you said. The only thing I would -- the only edit I would make is that actually when we acquired AirTran, their costs were not lower than ours interestingly enough, at least by my analysis. But clearly, the
componenttext: Yes, and let me just affirm virtually everything you said. The only thing I would -- the only edit I would make is that actually when we acquired AirTran, their costs were not lower than ours interestingly enough, at least by my analysis. But clearly, there are carriers today whose costs are lower. On that point, you and I certainly agree. And I -- first of all, I think that it is inevitable that, over time, that an industry will get more competitive, especially when there's a disruptor as there has been with Southwest Airlines. So it is not shocking at all that we have more intense competition today than at any time in our history. And it is a challenge for our company and something that I'm very confident that our people will rise up to that challenge. But indeed, it will put an obligation on us to continue to innovate and work very, very hard so that we don't lose our low-fare leadership position in the country. So absolutely, it is different and I think we recognize that the industry is more competitive today than it has been ever. I would quickly add, by the way, that Southwest has never been stronger. We've never had the route network. We've never had the depth and the breadth of the service that we offer. And we've never had a balance sheet this strong. We've never had earnings this strong. So it's really up to us to continue to make sure that we compete and be the best at service and price.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Excellent. Oh, I'm sorry, were you adding something there?
componenttext: Excellent. Oh, I'm sorry, were you adding something there?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, sir, that was it.
componenttext: No, sir, that was it.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Duane Pfennigwerth with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Duane Pfennigwerth with Evercore ISI.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the hedge liability that you called out for '16 and '17, appreciate that detail. I'm just wondering, can that change or is it fully locked in at this point? In other words, if fuel goes higher, does it shrink?
componenttext: So the hedge liability that you called out for '16 and '17, appreciate that detail. I'm just wondering, can that change or is it fully locked in at this point? In other words, if fuel goes higher, does it shrink?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It is -- if fuel goes higher, it certainly shrinks, so I'll start there. And no, it is not entirely locked in. But I think the main takeaway there is that we will -- as prices go down, so does our fuel bill as well. So yes, I gave you a pretty good amount
componenttext: It is -- if fuel goes higher, it certainly shrinks, so I'll start there. And no, it is not entirely locked in. But I think the main takeaway there is that we will -- as prices go down, so does our fuel bill as well. So yes, I gave you a pretty good amount of detail there on our hedge as I walked through our -- my comments there. So yes, I think we're positioned very well. We know what we have to manage and I think we're positioned well if fuel prices go up or if they go down from here.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then as we think about the capacity that you had in development last year in specifically the Wright Amendment markets, can you help us quantify the benefit you expect having less of that capacity in development? And if you can help us with sor
componenttext: Great. And then as we think about the capacity that you had in development last year in specifically the Wright Amendment markets, can you help us quantify the benefit you expect having less of that capacity in development? And if you can help us with sort of the full pie, maybe you could just talk about the markets that you launched in late 2014 that you should have had basically a year of experience with by the fourth quarter if you saw sort of significant RASM improvement there.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Duane, you were fading in and out, but I think we got the gist of your question. Yes, we have -- we can quantify, at least from an internal perspective, what we think the opportunity is there. I would just start out by acknowledging that, that assumes all
componenttext: Duane, you were fading in and out, but I think we got the gist of your question. Yes, we have -- we can quantify, at least from an internal perspective, what we think the opportunity is there. I would just start out by acknowledging that, that assumes all else is equal and -- but I'm sure that you and everyone else understand that, but Tammy, can I defer to you on that?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes. Just a couple of comments there to maybe help you out, Duane. We had, again, like you said, a high number -- high percentage of our markets were under development, you know what those markets are. And I'll remind you that the high percentages di
componenttext: Yes, yes. Just a couple of comments there to maybe help you out, Duane. We had, again, like you said, a high number -- high percentage of our markets were under development, you know what those markets are. And I'll remind you that the high percentages did include the markets that we were converting from AirTran over to Southwest. So the point I'm making there is not all of the markets are created equal. Obviously, we reported a lot on Dallas Love Field and are very pleased with how those markets are progressing. But we wouldn't expect our international markets, as an example, to mature at the rate we would, say, a Dallas or even the AirTran markets. So they're all a little bit different, but I can at least help quantify the impact we're expecting here in the first quarter. And if you -- it's probably in terms of -- it's probably a 1-point, I'd call it, maybe not even a 1-point impact from development markets. So as we move into 2016, at least my expectation would be that we'll get some tailwinds from our development markets as those continue to mature.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Rajeev Alawani (sic) [Rajeev Lalwani] with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Rajeev Alawani (sic) [Rajeev Lalwani] with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 for you guys. The first, I guess, with oil coming down so much and obviously you're going to see that benefit from the fuel numbers you provided. How does that impact how you're thinking about the business either from a revenue or a capacity standp
componenttext: Just 2 for you guys. The first, I guess, with oil coming down so much and obviously you're going to see that benefit from the fuel numbers you provided. How does that impact how you're thinking about the business either from a revenue or a capacity standpoint, if at all? And then second question was just you announced the aircraft order today and the acceleration. What drove that? What changed over the last couple of months? It seems like that opportunity has been out there for some time.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tammy, I'll take a shot and if you want to chime in, please do on both of those. The -- I would admit to you all that it is -- the year is off to a very concerning start when it comes to headlines around the world. It's almost as if we're living in a diff
componenttext: Tammy, I'll take a shot and if you want to chime in, please do on both of those. The -- I would admit to you all that it is -- the year is off to a very concerning start when it comes to headlines around the world. It's almost as if we're living in a different dimension here at Southwest and from what I've heard from some of our competitor reports, too. So our business continues to be strong, but I will quickly admit that there are concerning headlines around the world. So then you translate this to oil prices, and living in Texas my entire life, this is an oil and gas state, and yes, it is concerning the impact that it will have on companies and debt payments and jobs and so on. There's no question that the United States has benefited from the oil and gas boom that was occurring over the last X number of years since the -- really since the recession. So yes, that's all a concern that no doubt you have, we share that. But at least in terms of seeing any manifestation of that in our business, we just -- we don't see it. Even our oil and gas markets, if you want to call them that, produced very strong results in the fourth quarter. Several of our markets have year-over-year yield pressure, if you will, so that's not unique to those markets, but they still produced very, very handsome returns. But yes, it's just something we're going to have to keep our eye on. And I offer that background just as an acknowledgment that we're just living in a world where we need to continue to be alert and be cautious. I will then follow on and say that we felt like our plan for 2015 was sound and it turned out to be so. We think that the follow-on plan here for 2016 is also sound. It is more conservative than what we had committed ourselves to for last year. And as Tammy and I have both reiterated, we've not made any change with our capacity outlook and especially for 2016. We're still right in the 5% to 6% range. And I think all of us would be prepared that if, for whatever reason, travel demand weakens, then we would want to address that and then at least discuss what kind of options we have to react on the downside. But in terms of taking advantage -- further advantage of low energy prices and boosting our capacity, we don't have any plans to do that. So Tammy, before we go on to the second question, anything you would like to add?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think that was perfect, yes. And in terms of the -- your question on why did we decide to accelerate the classics, I guess, I'd just point back to our fleet modernization efforts that when we set our plan, I guess I just have to say we've been very
componenttext: No, I think that was perfect, yes. And in terms of the -- your question on why did we decide to accelerate the classics, I guess, I'd just point back to our fleet modernization efforts that when we set our plan, I guess I just have to say we've been very pleased with the benefits from our fleet modernizations so far. And as we continued to evaluate just the operating costs of operating classic as it dwindles in size, we just really took out our pencils, evaluated it and we were able to come up with a plan that actually is going to enable us to improve our EBIT with very -- at very modest capital levels. So I think you know Southwest well. We prefer a simplified fleet. And even though the classics fleet's a 737, we'd much prefer to operate 700s and 800s, it certainly simplifies a lot of the operations and also just improves the reliability in terms of just less downtime from a maintenance perspective. So I think we'll get -- also get a boost from the productivity of our fleet, which certainly was part of the EBIT contribution that we're expecting. So all in all, when we sat down and evaluated it, it became pretty compelling to go ahead and accelerate the classics. So hopefully, that helps provide a little color as to what went into the decision-making process. So Gary, did you have anything?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tammy, the only thing I would say about -- it's always a fair question to say, well, why now? Why not earlier? Why not later? And I think it's back to that convergence or confluence of things. First of all, we're at a fleet number that is manageable to th
componenttext: Tammy, the only thing I would say about -- it's always a fair question to say, well, why now? Why not earlier? Why not later? And I think it's back to that convergence or confluence of things. First of all, we're at a fleet number that is manageable to think about accelerating retirement in that way. We have more out-of-service time with those airplanes for maintenance reasons than we do the rest of our fleet. So and Tammy made that point, I just want to reiterate. You will get a lot more productivity out of a new airplane than what we are currently getting out of these classics, which means you don't necessarily even have to have a tail-by-tail replacement, although that is our plan. But they'll be more efficient. The other thing is that Boeing was available to us. Boeing had delivery positions and we were able to strike a deal with them in a way that was -- that worked for them, and was a win for them, it was a win for us. So that was key. With respect to our people, think about the people who have to touch the airplane, the pilots, flight attendants, mechanics especially, it's just far easier for our people to operate the next-gen than it is the classics. That's just a fact. So this will simplify a lot of things for all 3 of those workgroups, and in particular, our pilots. So it's a good deal. It works out -- it'll be better for our customers. And all the way around, we're just delighted that we have this alternative available and we were able to pull it all together at the end of the year. But it was an idea and a decision that was aggressively pursued in 2015, in fact, the latter part of 2015 and fortunately it all came together.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And just again, on the costs. Obviously, as always, it's just part of our DNA at Southwest, very focused on cost and being the low-cost producer and this is just yet another way to help us as we're managing our costs here over the next several years.
componenttext: Yes. And just again, on the costs. Obviously, as always, it's just part of our DNA at Southwest, very focused on cost and being the low-cost producer and this is just yet another way to help us as we're managing our costs here over the next several years.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Hunter Keay with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Hunter Keay with Wolfe Research.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: You guys didn't buy back stock in the quarter for the first time in almost 5 years. Looks like you still have some money left in the repo and I understand you did the $500 million ARS (sic) [ASR]. But I would have thought you guys would have come in and b
componenttext: You guys didn't buy back stock in the quarter for the first time in almost 5 years. Looks like you still have some money left in the repo and I understand you did the $500 million ARS (sic) [ASR]. But I would have thought you guys would have come in and bought some after cutting the revenue guide. Did that have anything to do -- not buying the stock have anything to do with posting $800-some-odd million in hedge collateral? Or can you give us any kind of color as to the thinking behind sort of putting it on hold for the quarter?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, Hunter, it didn't have anything to do with the fuel hedge collateral and honestly wouldn't read anything into that at all. We're focused -- as we said this morning, we're launching a $500 million accelerated share repurchase and so we're -- we'll get
componenttext: No, Hunter, it didn't have anything to do with the fuel hedge collateral and honestly wouldn't read anything into that at all. We're focused -- as we said this morning, we're launching a $500 million accelerated share repurchase and so we're -- we'll get that launched soon. And then after that, we will have $200 million remaining on our $1.5 billion, which was approved at our shareholder meeting last May. So we've gone through that authorization pretty darn quick, returning more than 100% of our free cash flow in 2014 to our shareholders. So very proud of what we did there in 2014 with respect to share repurchases. So again when -- actually, that included our dividend. So we are -- I don't think there's any anything larger than that.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and that was already a record amount. And as we've allowed here, we were also beginning to have serious thoughts and conversations with the Boeing Company and what -- how that cash flow might flow from that deal. So but I think what's material is tha
componenttext: Yes, and that was already a record amount. And as we've allowed here, we were also beginning to have serious thoughts and conversations with the Boeing Company and what -- how that cash flow might flow from that deal. So but I think what's material is that we've announced the $500 million today.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, okay. That's fair. And looks like when I look at schedule data, it looks like you guys are trimming a little bit of capacity out of Love Field market into LaGuardia and Reagan and moving some of that out west a little bit. Does that have anything to
componenttext: Yes, okay. That's fair. And looks like when I look at schedule data, it looks like you guys are trimming a little bit of capacity out of Love Field market into LaGuardia and Reagan and moving some of that out west a little bit. Does that have anything to do with the operational challenges that you might be encountering at Love Field because of the ongoing legal dispute? And obviously the ruling didn't go your way and you're going to appeal it. But does that have anything to do with that? Or is that unrelated and really the other factors maybe just sort of like market demand-based decisions? Any color around sort of what's going into that, if the schedule data's correct.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: You bet, you bet. Yes, sir, you bet. No, there's no -- I think our operations folks have done a marvelous job. They're doing what is for us 10 turns a day on a gate with well -- and less than full utilization of 18 gates. So the operation actually is doin
componenttext: You bet, you bet. Yes, sir, you bet. No, there's no -- I think our operations folks have done a marvelous job. They're doing what is for us 10 turns a day on a gate with well -- and less than full utilization of 18 gates. So the operation actually is doing fine, which simply means that we have -- when we finally get access to all the gates, we'll be able to put more flights in there. But you'll note, Hunter, that we make changes all over the country. And we don't make dramatic changes in Dallas, but you've got markets like Seattle that come to mind and Fort Myers, Florida where we make very significant seasonal adjustments. The other thing that I mentioned to the media on this very same question this morning is that with -- you know that we have a lot of new flying that's transpired since October 2014, and I went through all that stuff and so has Tammy. So with all of those new routes, I think we would readily admit to you that, in some cases, we may not -- we may have too many flights in some places, we may not have enough flights in places and so there's always some tuning that continues. And that is all that's going on here at Love Field. So my recollection, we're still at 180 daily departures, which probably cut through everything and answers your questions best that way. But yes, we've got some pluses and minuses in routes and there's nothing unusual about that.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Savi Syth with Raymond James.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Savi Syth with Raymond James.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the unit cost growth. I was just kind of curious with the higher capacity growth in the first half, I would have thought maybe -- a little surprised by a 2% CASM-Ex growth. And I'm just wondering, I know the 1 point from the accelerated depreciati
componenttext: Just on the unit cost growth. I was just kind of curious with the higher capacity growth in the first half, I would have thought maybe -- a little surprised by a 2% CASM-Ex growth. And I'm just wondering, I know the 1 point from the accelerated depreciation, just wondering if there were timing -- cost timing issues? Or what was leading to that slightly higher increase in 1Q?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, you're exactly right, Savi. The guidance for the full year is 1%. So you're exactly right. It's just a timing of when our expenses are falling.
componenttext: Yes, you're exactly right, Savi. The guidance for the full year is 1%. So you're exactly right. It's just a timing of when our expenses are falling.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then another -- just on the ULCC question that came up before. Just wondering, Gary, maybe if you have any thoughts here. It seems like the industry was going through a bit of a segmentation and I know Southwest wants to be kind of the leading
componenttext: Got it. And then another -- just on the ULCC question that came up before. Just wondering, Gary, maybe if you have any thoughts here. It seems like the industry was going through a bit of a segmentation and I know Southwest wants to be kind of the leading low-cost, low-fare airline. But there is a product differential and then -- be it your kind of on-time performance or be it the product, the service, a myriad of things. I was just kind of curious as to what your thought process is. Do you need to be the lowest fare, recognizing that there is a difference in product? And then maybe your thoughts on kind of the customer segmentation if there is a customer segmentation? Or if it's -- if this is a -- truly like a commodity business and you just have to be -- have the lowest fares?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I love your question. I love everybody's question, but that, I think that's one that's an interesting one to share and I'm happy to have an opportunity to address it. We want to be the best service at the lowest price, period. And in describing pric
componenttext: Well, I love your question. I love everybody's question, but that, I think that's one that's an interesting one to share and I'm happy to have an opportunity to address it. We want to be the best service at the lowest price, period. And in describing price, I would agree that we're going to have to do some comparisons between unbundled pricing versus our more bundled approach. All-in, I want Southwest Airlines to be the lowest price. We'll win if we have the best service at the lowest price. And that's been our tradition, that's been our history, that's what the whole company is based upon and that's what our growth plans are fundamentally based upon. I think it is a slippery slope to accept that our costs and our fares can be higher based on service because, as you well know, there is a long list of failures in the airline industry who pursued that exact strategic plan. And it's really a cop-out, it's really not facing up to the challenges of finding more and better ways to compete on cost and on price. So the thing I love about Southwest is it's been a company who's been able to do both. And the other thing that you find, I think, which is a slippery slope is companies can change. And while service may not be a great attribute for some of our competitors today who will go unnamed, who's to say that they can't change that in the future? And so we need to continue to strive to be the best at both and we need -- while we may not have all the answers at any given point in time, I think that, that needs to continue to be our guiding light.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our last question from Michael Linenberg with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: We'll take our last question from Michael Linenberg with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two quick ones here. When we started the quarter, the guide was for RASM to be up about 1%. And as we moved through much of the quarter, that number was out there and then, I don't know, about a month back, you took guidance down. And when I think about a
componenttext: Two quick ones here. When we started the quarter, the guide was for RASM to be up about 1%. And as we moved through much of the quarter, that number was out there and then, I don't know, about a month back, you took guidance down. And when I think about across the industry, we did see some of the carriers come in with weaker-than-expected unit revenues. Some of it was fuel surcharges, some of it was FX. Some of it was the Paris attacks. Those are the types of things that I didn't think impacted you on one hand. Then on the other, we did hear that some airlines just ran a better operation because the winter weather wasn't that bad. So I'm curious with your exposure in the energy patch, I mean, was that some of it that you saw some demand weakness in your core energy markets? Or is it just a better-run operation? I mean, what drove that down so much?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, and I don't think Tammy would either, I wouldn't blame our energy markets at all. Although, as I mentioned earlier, I think it is true that the energy markets are seeing some softness in RASM year-over-year, but they're still really healthy. I think
componenttext: Mike, and I don't think Tammy would either, I wouldn't blame our energy markets at all. Although, as I mentioned earlier, I think it is true that the energy markets are seeing some softness in RASM year-over-year, but they're still really healthy. I think the thing that's -- and Tammy will have better insights, no doubt, but the thing that stands out to me was Thanksgiving. We were pretty much tracking along with our forecast for the quarter until then. And it was all -- if you'll recall our discussion with our November traffic, the pricing environment was not -- it was -- I used the word, it was quoted at the time, it was unusual. So the Christmas holiday period was more normal. But regardless, you kind of fast-forward now, and Tammy, maybe you -- maybe it might be more helpful to talk about current trends as opposed to what -- but that -- Mike, that was the main thing that I recalled in the fourth quarter was the yields over the week of Thanksgiving holiday travel based on unusual discounting in the industry were lower than what we would have predicted. But anything you want to add there, Tammy?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Gary, I agree. That really was what was -- that was primarily what was different from what our forecast was going into the quarter. But we ended the year with the holiday performance in December, that was actually within our expectations. So as we're
componenttext: Yes, Gary, I agree. That really was what was -- that was primarily what was different from what our forecast was going into the quarter. But we ended the year with the holiday performance in December, that was actually within our expectations. So as we're just trying to sort through all of that, I would just -- our expectation going into the first quarter, based on what we've seen so far in January, is demand seems strong. We're continuing to see strong load factors. But again, we're also continuing to see them come in at weaker yields. So that -- so at least, I guess the way I would characterize it, at least from what we're seeing so far, in our bookings is stabilized.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, the only other thing I would just point out is we had the same question here after the -- so Thanksgiving occurred after the Paris attacks and whether there was an effect on bookings with us, with our -- I don't know. That's hard to tease out of all
componenttext: Mike, the only other thing I would just point out is we had the same question here after the -- so Thanksgiving occurred after the Paris attacks and whether there was an effect on bookings with us, with our -- I don't know. That's hard to tease out of all that. But the other thing that's going on here is you look at the broader GDP results for the fourth quarter and they weren't very good. So it's possible that the industry was seeing some softening in demand that led to more aggressive discounting and it's coupled with the industry also growing faster than GDP. So it wouldn't be shocking to find that there was a little bit of a rough patch there and just trying to get supply and demand cleared at the right price. So but in any event, beyond that, we're continuing to manage our developing markets. We're continuing to manage our markets in which there are competitive changes in terms of pluses and minuses in activity. And overall, the demand, as we said, demand it all adds up to a, I think, a very solid outlook. And I'll just reiterate one more time that our results are not adjusted for the difference in stage, length and gauge. If you do that, we're turning in positive unit revenue performances in the fourth quarter, for the full year 2015 and that would also continue to be our outlook in the first quarter.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a good point. And then just on capacity, I apologize if you threw this out there, Tammy, but I think you gave the full year number, 5% to 6%, which is obviously unchanged. But normally around this time of the year you'd give it to us by quarter. An
componenttext: That's a good point. And then just on capacity, I apologize if you threw this out there, Tammy, but I think you gave the full year number, 5% to 6%, which is obviously unchanged. But normally around this time of the year you'd give it to us by quarter. And the way it seems, it seems like it would be front end-loaded, obviously impacted by the leap day. Do you have kind of rough -- what those rates are by quarter, how we should model it for the year?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Has Southwest recently exited any fuel hedge contracts early for further participation in the fuel price decline? And if so, at what cost?
componenttext: Has Southwest recently exited any fuel hedge contracts early for further participation in the fuel price decline? And if so, at what cost?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll be happy to take that. We have reduced our hedges here in 2016, so the answer to that question would be yes. We -- I guess, just looking at what we had last reported to you in terms of our hedge percentages, I guess the main difference would be
componenttext: Yes, I'll be happy to take that. We have reduced our hedges here in 2016, so the answer to that question would be yes. We -- I guess, just looking at what we had last reported to you in terms of our hedge percentages, I guess the main difference would be in the second half of 2016. So we did reduce our hedges there substantially in light of the declining fuel market. So we went from, call it, 60% to 70% in the second half of 2016 to probably closer to 30% to 35%.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: So in other words, we were already long with a position for '16 and '17 as 2015 unfolded. headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Southwest Airlines First Quarter 2016 Conference Call. My name is Tom, and I'll be moderating today's call. Today's conference is being recorded and a replay will be available on southwest.com in the Investor Relations section.At this tim
componenttext:
Welcome to the Southwest Airlines First Quarter 2016 Conference Call. My name is Tom, and I'll be moderating today's call. Today's conference is being recorded and a replay will be available on southwest.com in the Investor Relations section.
At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to Ms. Marcy Brand, Managing Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, ma'am.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to today's call to discuss our first quarter 2016 results. Joining the call today, we have Gary Kelly, Chairman, President and CEO; Tammy Romo, Executive Vice President and CFO; Bob Jordan, Executive Vic
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to today's call to discuss our first quarter 2016 results. Joining the call today, we have Gary Kelly, Chairman, President and CEO; Tammy Romo, Executive Vice President and CFO; Bob Jordan, Executive Vice President and Chief Commercial Officer; and Mike Van De Ven, Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer.
Please note today's call will include forward-looking statements and because these statements are based on the company's current intent, expectations and projections, they are not guarantees of future performance and a variety of factors could cause actual results to differ materially.
As this call will include references to non-GAAP results, excluding special items, please reference this morning's press release in the Investor Relations section of southwest.com for further information regarding forward-looking statements and reconciliations of non-GAAP results to GAAP results.
At this time, I'd like to go ahead and turn the call over to Gary for opening remarks.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Marcy, and good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our first quarter earnings call. We are absolutely delighted with these results and considering the quality of our operation, the hospitality of our customer service and these strong
componenttext:
Thank you, Marcy, and good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our first quarter earnings call. We are absolutely delighted with these results and considering the quality of our operation, the hospitality of our customer service and these strong profits, it is absolutely the best start we've had to a year and over 2 decades so I'm very, very pleased.
Of course, a big driver in our 33% earnings per share growth is a lower jet fuel price but the revenue performance was also superb. This year is essentially the follow through to a healthy expansion that began back in 2014 with the repeal of the Wright Amendment and then the aggressive expansion out of Dallas Love Field and that was followed by the integration and conversion of AirTran at year end 2014 and that generated a lot of new flights in Southwest as well. Following the AirTran conversion, we launched 4 new international cities in 2015, as well as a new terminal and domestic gateway at Houston Hobby. So you add all that up and it's a 9.2% capacity growth here in the first quarter. Would certainly admit that, that is a lot and what is impressive is that our revenue growth kept pace. So we continue to experience outstanding performance out of Dallas Love Field. The rest of our developing markets are providing a very nice tailwind as well as they continue along an expected maturity path.
Last year at this time, we had about 20% of our system in development and this year because we have intentionally slowed the additions of new markets, we have only about 5% in development.
And of course as a backdrop, the industry is adding fleets aggressively. It's a very competitive environment. Of course, that's all fine with us. We have low cost and we have a great low fare brand but we've been very pleased with the consistent strong demand for the Southwest product resulting in yet another record load factor in the first quarter and numerous other records for that matter. But the point is even in the face of our growth and the in intensely competitive environment, we're doing really, really well.
And I would attribute that to a couple of things. First and foremost, to our people and the terrific service that they offer our customers every single day. I'm very proud of them and of course, I congratulate them on these great results and the record profit sharing that they've earned. I also attribute our results to our strong domestic network where we offer more seats and board more customers than any other airline.
Our marketing department, in particular, has done a terrific job of distilling our message with our advertising campaign on transparency, the customer awareness of the low fare value that you get with Southwest is very high and that timing of that campaign matches perfectly with the incredible momentum that we have had with our record rewards loyalty program. So we have a strong profitable network, we have great service, low fares with nothing to hide. We have an award-winning loyalty program and all of that served up by outstanding employees. So we are exceptionally well-positioned to compete and grow and we intend to keep it just that way.
Now before I turn it over to Tammy, I have noticed that some of the reports this morning, a little bit of confusion, so I did want to make an opening clarifying point, which is with the now early retirement of our classic fleet. I just want to be sure that everyone understands that what we said in our press release is that means that the growth rate will be less, not that our capacity will be less. So we will still grow, available seat miles under any scenario that we contemplated in 2017 compared to 2016 and then the same would be true also for 2018 as compared to 2017. The point is that the growth rates in '17 will no doubt be less than it should have been.
So Tammy, with those opening remarks, let me just turn it over to you to take us through the quarter, please, ma'am.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gary, and welcome, everyone. We're thrilled to report on our exceptionally strong first quarter results. Net income, excluding special items, increased almost 26% year-over-year to a record $567 million and earnings per share grew 33%. This repres
componenttext:
Thanks, Gary, and welcome, everyone. We're thrilled to report on our exceptionally strong first quarter results. Net income, excluding special items, increased almost 26% year-over-year to a record $567 million and earnings per share grew 33%. This represented our 12th consecutive quarter of record profit. Our revenue results remained at record levels and we continue to benefit from low fuel prices and our ongoing fleet modernization efforts. We expanded our operating margin, excluding special items to 19.7%, which is the highest it's been in more than 35 years and our pretax return on invested capital, excluding special items for the 12 months ended March 2016, was 33.4%, which well exceeded our cost of capital on an after-tax basis.
Just a fantastic start to the year and I'd also like to congratulate our wonderful employees on these outstanding results and their record first quarter profit sharing of $155 million.
Our strong revenue performance in first quarter was a significant driver of our record first quarter earnings. Operating revenues grew to a record $4.8 billion and our passenger revenues also grew to record levels. Strong demand for our low friendly fares and the overall strength of our network were contributing factors to our 9.3% increase in revenues.
We're pleased with the performance of our development markets that resulted in about 1 point net tailwind to RASM in first quarter. International markets also performed in line with our expectations including our new Houston markets and Dallas continues to produce solid results with load factor expansion and strong margins in first quarter.
Our Rapid Rewards revenue production was very strong in the quarter, including approximately $125 million, a year-over-year incremental revenue from our amended co-brand agreement with Chase last July, and our ancillary revenues continued to perform very well.
Our revenue growth was in line with our capacity, resulting in flat RASM, which was industry-leading and notable considering the 1 to 2-point impact from our stage engage increase in first quarter. All around, I'm very pleased with our first quarter revenue performance.
While the weak yield environment has continued into second quarter, demand so far has remained solid and based on our current bookings and revenue trends, we are expecting a modest growth in second quarter, 2016 RASM performance year-over-year. And just as a reminder again, this outlook includes roughly $125 million from the Chase agreement and accounting change that -- just as a reminder that we will lapse that year-over-year benefit in the third quarter.
Our freight revenue was down slightly year-over-year and other revenue production was boosted by the Chase agreement but also by a 12% increase in ancillary revenues, mostly from growth in EarlyBirds and our upgraded boarding product. We currently expect second quarter 2016 freight and other revenues to increase from second quarter last year.
Turning to our cost. We are very pleased with our first quarter cost performance. Our operating unit cost, excluding special items, decreased 2.6% year-over-year from ongoing fleet modernization benefits, weather and lower jet fuel prices. Our economic fuel price per gallon declined 11% year-over-year to $1.78. The year-over-year decline was driven primarily by lower crude and heating oil prices offset by higher hedging year-over-year. We ended up a little higher than our previous guide at the beginning of March simply due to the increase in the crude and heating oil since that time. And based on market prices as of Monday and our second quarter hedge, that remains unchanged. We currently expect our fuel price per gallon to be in the $1.75 to $1.80 range. And for full-year 2016, we currently expect to fall in the $1.85 to $1.90 range based on current market prices.
Excluding fuel and special items, our unit cost were comparable to first quarter last year and down slightly when you also include, excuse me, exclude profit-sharing. This was better than our previous guidance due to milder weather and associated costs avoided, as well as ship to projects spend to later this year.
Based on our current cost trends, we expect second quarter 2016 CASM excluding fuel special items to profit sharing to increase approximately 2% year-over-year. And roughly 1 point of the year-over-year increase is driven by accelerated depreciation from our Classics retirement. And the remainder of the cost inflation is largely as a result of timing of advertising and technology investments.
For our -- for the full year 2016, we continue to estimate a modest 1% increase in our unit costs, excluding fuel, special items and profit-sharing, which again is driven entirely by the accelerated depreciation.
Our balance sheet and cash flows remain very strong and our cash and short-term investments were $3.6 billion at the end of the quarter. We allowed our cash to build a bit as we plan to fund our 2015 profit-sharing accrual later this month and we also intend to launch a $200 million accelerated share repurchase, which will be completed next month.
Our record free cash flow was $1.2 billion as a result of strong operating cash flow of $1.6 billion and $438 million of capital spend. For our full-year 2016, we continue to estimate manageable CapEx of approximately $2 billion.
We returned a $596 million to shareholders in share repurchases and dividends in the first quarter and as I previously mentioned, we will be launching a $200 million accelerated share repurchase this month to complete our current $1.5 billion repurchase authorization and this was on the heels of returning $1.4 billion to our shareholders in 2015. Returning significant value to our shareholders remains a priority along with preserving the strength of our balance sheet and cash flow.
Our leverage including balance sheet aircraft leases remains in the low to mid-30% range and we are very proud of our strong balance sheet and we remain the only domestic airlines with an investment grade rating from all 3 rating agencies.
So before I wrap up, I'd like to spend just a little bit of time going over our announcement this morning regarding our Classics retirement fleet plans. So as you will recall in January, we announced our intent to retire our Classics fleet no later than mid-2018. Earlier this month, we made the decision to refine the acceleration date to no later than third quarter 2017 to allow for our Classics fleet to be retired ahead of our planned operating date of the Boeing -800 Max aircraft. By doing so, we'll alleviate the potential of training complexities related to operating both the classic and MAX aircraft. Boeing and FAA aren't expected to determine their training requirements of operating the Classics MAX Air until May of 2017 at the earliest, which doesn't allow adequate time to be trained and operationally ready for a 2017 MAX launch. So our preference to address the undefined FAA requirement with this segment, Classics and MAX lines. We've been working with the swap and negotiating team to come up with a mutually beneficial solution to address the segmentation but unfortunately, we've been able to come to any agreement.
So in order to move forward with our plan to watch the launch of MAX, we must proceed with a solution, which retiring our Classics fleet no later than third quarter '17 provides.
So as a result of this decision, we'll have about 50 fewer aircraft than previously planned in fourth quarter 2017, which obviously also creates less capacity. And again as Gary mentioned, we intend to have capacity growth but just this decision alone creates less capacity than what we had previously planned.
That said, we're evaluating our options given these circumstances and believe we have a lot of flexibility to manage through the temporary dip in our fleet as we did with the 717s, including utilization of our fleets.
So with that in mind, we continue to expect our year-over-year fleet growth for the 3 years ended 2018 to average no more than 2% and again, our annual year-over-year capacity over that period is still expected to peak this year at 5% to 6%. While we'll continue to evaluate our fleet plans based on where we are today, our aircraft CapEx forecast remains in the $1.3 billion to $1.4 billion range for this year.
And while I mentioned that before, our preference for a number of reasons would have been to segment our fleet, however, we still estimate and even improvement of at least $200 million from accelerating the Classics from the 2021 timeframe to 2017, again largely driven by maintenance and fuel savings. This is net of the impact of the estimated accelerated depreciation of approximately $130 million that will largely be expensed during 2016. And of course, accelerating our Classics retirement results in an improved customer service even faster with a fully equipped Wi-Fi suite by the end of third quarter of next year.
So with regards to capacity just again, to be clear we continue to plan for 5% to 6% year-over-year growth this year. Our second and third quarter ASMs will increase in the 4% to 5% range and we will be publishing our fourth quarter schedule in May, which will go through January 4 of next year. And as we've noted previously, the majority of 2016 capacity growth is related to the annualized impact of 2015 unit expansion opportunities. While our capacity plans beyond 2016 are yet to be determined, we do expect 2017 and 2018 year-over-year ASM growth to been down from 2016's levels. We will remain disciplined in our approach to growth with our focus of flexibility to adjust and with a goal to preserve strong returns and margins.
So in conclusion, we had another record quarter with or without the benefit of substantially lower fuel prices, our earnings and margins improved year-over-year, demand remains strong producing record revenues and our outlook for second quarter suggests positive operating unit revenue growth. Our cost outlook for the year is for modest inflation driven largely by our decision to accelerate the retirement of the Classics fleet even faster than we've previously announced, which is expected to produce significant cost savings and even improvement of at least $200 million.
Fuel prices remain lower year-over-year and we have had very strong free cash flow this year and our balance sheet is strong as ever. We've continued our commitment to reach our value to shareholders and intend to complete our current authorization with the launch of a $200 million ASR by the end of this month and we will continue to prudently manage our capital spend and we'll remain disciplined in our valuation of future growth opportunities.
Again, our pretax return on invested capital was an exceptional 33.4%. Our outlook for second quarter supports another quarter of strong margins likely in excess of first quarter's of 19.7% and with that, I'd like to close by thanking our employees again for another fantastic quarter.
So Tom, we'll be happy to open it up for questions now.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
