componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll now begin with our first question from Rajeev Lalwani with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you just talk about the rising trend from year? Obviously, you had a nice increase going to the second quarter but as we think about just the rest of the year and of the credit card deal, is it going to be a hard for you to stand up positive on that t
componenttext: Can you just talk about the rising trend from year? Obviously, you had a nice increase going to the second quarter but as we think about just the rest of the year and of the credit card deal, is it going to be a hard for you to stand up positive on that territory. And that's the first question. And then the second is, you talked about kind of evaluating or looking at a range of options to address some of the Classic flying. Can you just talk about what those range of options are? Is there the potential for more CapEx for more orders or anything like that?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd be happy to start with your question regarding RASM trends. So I'll just walk you through the quarter a bit. So just at the highest level, January and February RASM were slightly down and then margin was slightly up, which got us to the roughly flat u
componenttext: I'd be happy to start with your question regarding RASM trends. So I'll just walk you through the quarter a bit. So just at the highest level, January and February RASM were slightly down and then margin was slightly up, which got us to the roughly flat unit revenue comparison with about $15 million of benefit from Easter in March. So April, we're at RASM adjusted for Easter is currently running in line with March and as you think about the comparisons as we move forward in the quarter, we expected to improve as a result of the increased competitive environment that we began experiencing in May and June of last year. And then, of course, as a reminder again, we'll continue to have the year-over-year benefit from the Chase agreement, at least through the second quarter here. So again, I think we're positioned very well here as we start second quarter and I would just characterize the demand environment as solid. And so at this point, adjust -- we're continuing to see the same sort of trends that we saw in the first quarter.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry, what about for the rest of the year and keeping that trend going, especially with the Chase agreement I think?
componenttext: Sorry, what about for the rest of the year and keeping that trend going, especially with the Chase agreement I think?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's hard to predict further out in the year. Certainly, we're off to a good start here in the second quarter and as you pointed out, the comparisons do become more difficult in the second half because of we lapsed the benefit of the Chase agreeme
componenttext: I think it's hard to predict further out in the year. Certainly, we're off to a good start here in the second quarter and as you pointed out, the comparisons do become more difficult in the second half because of we lapsed the benefit of the Chase agreement.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I might take up the -- unless you have anymore questions on that, Rajeev, I might take up the fleet question for a second. I think it is the usual suspects that are available to us. We can tweak the utilization of the aircraft, which translates to a lo
componenttext: So I might take up the -- unless you have anymore questions on that, Rajeev, I might take up the fleet question for a second. I think it is the usual suspects that are available to us. We can tweak the utilization of the aircraft, which translates to a longer duty day of the airplane. I'm not sure that that's what we want to do but that is an option. Yes, in other words, just flying later, earlier and later in the day. We can search the used market for more 700s and we have some options as you know by our fleet chart, we have options that can be exercised as well, which would translate to more -- to be clear, that will be more capital spending. That's not in Tammy's capital spending guidance that in other words, the capital spending guidance does not assume the exercise of any options, to be clear. In no scenario that we've talked about would we bring in 50 more airplanes. And Mike, I don't recall exactly how many aircraft will be ultimately retired under the previous scenario, but I'm going to guess it was around 30 that would have been retired in one step, 30-ish. So the 50 is not quite as large as it might sound although again that's a large number but where already retiring a fair number of aircraft in 2018. So as I said in the press release, this is all manageable. It's not preferable. It's all manageable, and we're just not -- the first thing that we wanted to share with all of our team and of course you all as well is that, that is going to happen, of that being the Classic retirement acceleration. Now the company can go to work on translating that into maintenance programs for that fleet to now retire earlier that will avoid some maintenance spending as Tammy has already made clear. And then we can explore other options as far as bringing either leased equipment in or exercising some options and spending a little bit more capital. But I think the other thing just to make sure that everybody is clear in their head on is we -- our projected fleet at the end of 2018 is unaffected by any of this. So you're simply talking about accelerating retirements from 2018 into 2017. And that makes this all for us a little bit easier. And another reason why we want to be thoughtful about bringing on more airplanes to replace that. So all of that is still an open question. And as soon as we make some choices there, I'm sure we'll be sharing those.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: We'll take our next question from Jamie Baker from JPMorgan.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Gary, on the topic of the Classics, is the decision potentially reversible and how much lead time would you need if you did negotiate a solution to keep these airplanes in the fourth quarter of '17? I'm trying to assess it lower capacity is a done deal here or if this is merely a shot across, slop it can be revisited at the negotiating table?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I read your note earlier so I'm glad you asked me the question because one thing I wanted to clarify, this was not a shot contrary to the way our industry is worked with employees in the past, that's not the way we do business here at Southwest so..
componenttext: Well, I read your note earlier so I'm glad you asked me the question because one thing I wanted to clarify, this was not a shot contrary to the way our industry is worked with employees in the past, that's not the way we do business here at Southwest so...

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, duly noted.
componenttext: Okay, duly noted.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's -- you know that, just wanted to be sure that all of our listeners know that. But that's not what this is about. We're here to take care of our people and clearly accelerating this retirement is not going to be a good thing for our employees. It's no
componenttext: It's -- you know that, just wanted to be sure that all of our listeners know that. But that's not what this is about. We're here to take care of our people and clearly accelerating this retirement is not going to be a good thing for our employees. It's not a bad thing but we're not at war with our people. We're at war with our competitors, number one. On -- with respect to whether it is negotiable, well, and that spirit, of course, we want to continue to work with the pilots union in particular to do what we can to keep our cost competitive and grow this airline so that we can be as competitive as possible. I don't realistically see a scenario, Mike, where we can -- I mean that's why we're sharing this today. It's not so much that it is a decision. I don't see that we have any choice because we have to begin to put plans into effect for training, maintenance and then, if we are going to go out and try to mitigate the earlier retirement, we've got to be working on that and I'm sure sooner than later,  we'll want to make commitments there. So as a practical matter, I think that's a done deal and I just -- to be blunt, I just don't see swap moving on their position regarding segmentation. So there's a practical my thing I think it's a done deal.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I appreciate the color. On the topic of the pilot swap and the pilot offer from last month, it did looked pretty rich to us represented over 2 points of CASM by our analysis and then that's just the pilots all in, it's getting hard to imagine how th
componenttext: Okay, I appreciate the color. On the topic of the pilot swap and the pilot offer from last month, it did looked pretty rich to us represented over 2 points of CASM by our analysis and then that's just the pilots all in, it's getting hard to imagine how the entirety of your new contracts won't increase x-fuel CASM by 4 points possibly more if it was rolled up into a single year. What assurances, Gary, can you give us that you possess sufficient revenue initiatives that can offset this cost pressure? Or do we just have to assume that post-labor, Southwest will have lower, still very good but lower margins than today on the fuel-neutral basis?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, great questions. Obviously, it is very important for us to maintain our low fare brand and our low fare brand is not negotiable. In order to have a business in a low fare brand, we have to have that supported by low costs. So that's what the company
componenttext: Well, great questions. Obviously, it is very important for us to maintain our low fare brand and our low fare brand is not negotiable. In order to have a business in a low fare brand, we have to have that supported by low costs. So that's what the company was founded on 45 years ago and we're certainly not going to re-trade that. All these negotiations meet their complex, they take a long time and especially in light of the fact that we are in mediation, where the mediator has asked us to maintain confidentiality about what is discussed. I know you don't expect me to go into any detail but I certainly want to honor that request for confidentiality. But all of these just has to be addressed at the negotiating table with an eye towards rewarding our people and compensating them handsomely but doing that in a way where we maintain productivity and efficiency so we sustain our low-cost structure. So what I can give you assurance on is that we have not wavered in our desire to achieve that goal. And we'll have to continue to work together with our union leadership to be able to live up to that.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Hunter Keay with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: We'll go next to Hunter Keay with Wolfe Research.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Gary, or maybe Bob, if you're there at 2, when you think about the heavy mix of connecting traffic at Love Field, even more specifically on the Wright Amendment routes being so high like well above 40% I think. It looks like you may have sort of inadve
componenttext: So Gary, or maybe Bob, if you're there at 2, when you think about the heavy mix of connecting traffic at Love Field, even more specifically on the Wright Amendment routes being so high like well above 40% I think. It looks like you may have sort of inadvertently created rolling off of there. So think about that in the context of a new market development, how satisfied are you right now with their ability to manage yields in Dallas on an oil basis given all those connections? And is that an opportunity to sort of knew for you guys that maybe has a little bit of underappreciated upside that even you yourself aren't able to quantify right now?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm going to let Bob speak to that as well. And he is here, he is sitting right by me. The -- no, actually, I feel like the Dallas Love Field operation is pretty much in line with what I would have expected except as I admitted to you all before, th
componenttext: Well, I'm going to let Bob speak to that as well. And he is here, he is sitting right by me. The -- no, actually, I feel like the Dallas Love Field operation is pretty much in line with what I would have expected except as I admitted to you all before, the rapid development of those markets and the full flights actually took me a little bit by surprise. I thought it would take us a while longer to produce the kind of results we have there. Tammy, I did glance this morning earlier, the returns out of Dallas are still right at system average, maybe just a hair below for the first quarter. So simply meaning, Hunter, that it is -- I would not call Dallas in development, clearly Bob, is going to disagree and say there are certain markets at who want to better performance but overall as an entity, it looks really good. I've never noticed any remarkable difference in the O&D mix versus connects -- Dallas versus any other place. Sounds like you've been studying this but as our intent would be to have Chicago, St. Louis, Phoenix, Baltimore -- all of those very large operation -- Houston, all of those very large operations look roughly the same. And I don't -- I'm not seeing anything that says so that it is remarkably different. And I certainly haven't seen anything so far to suggest that there is any disappointment whatsoever in Dallas.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no Hunter, this is Bob, and thanks for the question. I think a couple of things, our Dallas performance is right in line with the system as Gary said. Now we built Dallas up in a serious sort of tranches of adding flights. And so some groupings of fli
componenttext: No, no Hunter, this is Bob, and thanks for the question. I think a couple of things, our Dallas performance is right in line with the system as Gary said. Now we built Dallas up in a serious sort of tranches of adding flights. And so some groupings of flights are more mature than others. So I'll say that the last couple of groupings that we added, which are obviously younger are continuing to develop and we'll see that confident over time. So there's still room for improvement in Dallas even though it is right at system average. The traffic mix, just because Dallas is constrained, always remember, we love to have more flights in Dallas than we can have and so because of that, were always going to bias for local traffic more than we would in an unconstrained large city like a Chicago for example. So we do -- because we could have more capacity in Dallas, Dallas will always I think slightly under weight the flow and connect traffic compared to what it could be if we were not constrained because we've got to make room for local traffic, which again there's more local traffic demand than we have room for at the gates and flights that we have in Dallas.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hunter, the only thing I would add to what we both said is that we're conscious of this. We -- there are some analogies to Love Field around the country that I won't mention but we do have techniques where we can influence one way or the other. So we're v
componenttext: Hunter, the only thing I would add to what we both said is that we're conscious of this. We -- there are some analogies to Love Field around the country that I won't mention but we do have techniques where we can influence one way or the other. So we're very happy with the way Dallas is performing. Again, it's a constrained market as we know so we'll have to continue to keep an eye on it. But I don't know if we're hitting the point of your question or not.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I know it's -- we can maybe take this off-line. I want to ask another question, that is good enough for now. And then if I back out the $125 million credit card benefit, it looks like unless some stuff move there out in the P&L I'm not aware, looks l
componenttext: Yes, I know it's -- we can maybe take this off-line. I want to ask another question, that is good enough for now. And then if I back out the $125 million credit card benefit, it looks like unless some stuff move there out in the P&L I'm not aware, looks like your other revenue is 35%. The first is, is that right? And if so, what is that? Tammy mentioned earlier EarlyBird 12% and once we lapse the credit card, how should we think about that other revenue growth rate in the third quarter and beyond? Because again, I'm just curious if my underlying math and how should we think about beyond once we lapse your credit card?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Hunter, I'd be happy to help with that. Yes, we are seeing strong growth in our other. The -- just as a reminder of our -- just so you know, the components of the benefit from our credit card fall if you -- of the net is around $124 million and other
componenttext: Yes, Hunter, I'd be happy to help with that. Yes, we are seeing strong growth in our other. The -- just as a reminder of our -- just so you know, the components of the benefit from our credit card fall if you -- of the net is around $124 million and other revenues were increased by about call it $175 million and passenger revenues were decreased by about $50 million. So the -- I'm not sure if you did the math exactly right there but that's the split of the net, $100 million and roughly $125 million benefit from Chase. But we're continuing to see strong ancillary revenues. We've had strong EarlyBird revenues and -- but again, aside...

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have more back fleets, we have more WiFi, we have more pets, we have -- the others are collection with you. I can't attest to your math either but I am certain that we have a very strong growth in the core group of ancillary revenues.
componenttext: We have more back fleets, we have more WiFi, we have more pets, we have -- the others are collection with you. I can't attest to your math either but I am certain that we have a very strong growth in the core group of ancillary revenues.

componenttext: And so, yes ...

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Andrew Didora with Bank of America.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Andrew Didora with Bank of America.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, Gary, you spoke about this in your prepared remarks but one of the reasons you have been posing industry-leading revenues of late has been the maturation of many of your routes. As you look at the impact over the course of the year, do you think
componenttext: I guess, Gary, you spoke about this in your prepared remarks but one of the reasons you have been posing industry-leading revenues of late has been the maturation of many of your routes. As you look at the impact over the course of the year, do you think this maturation is having a bigger impact on revenue today or call it the first half of the year? Or do you think this accelerates to the back half of the year? I guess any color you could provide around the timing of that would be helpful.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It feels like it will trend away from us. So in other words, it's higher today than it should be a year from now. I also think that there's quite a bit of artwork that we're debating internally about how to define a development market. So we're seeing rea
componenttext: It feels like it will trend away from us. So in other words, it's higher today than it should be a year from now. I also think that there's quite a bit of artwork that we're debating internally about how to define a development market. So we're seeing really broad strength in our cities and Bob, I don't think we call an additional frequency in the market that's existing. We don't call that "Development" So I think the impact is likely larger than the point of that Tammy shared with you. I think all of our folks agree with that. So we maybe a little bit conservative and that may be a conservative outlook as a consequence of that. But the other thing is not only is the existing maturing but we're also slowing down the pace of stopping in new and that is all intentional. So we'll have a pretty conservative year in 2016 in terms of incremental flying that's being added between now and the end of the year and that will help as well. So the tailwind should exist all year long and I think it will begin to diminish roughly a year from now.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's very helpful. And also just wanted to touch upon the balance sheet and capital returns. I guess with no change right now in terms of your CapEx expand, do you think we could see a pickup in the pace of buybacks particularly as I guess fuel st
componenttext: Okay, that's very helpful. And also just wanted to touch upon the balance sheet and capital returns. I guess with no change right now in terms of your CapEx expand, do you think we could see a pickup in the pace of buybacks particularly as I guess fuel stays lower, a little bit lower for longer now. I guess any color you may provide and how you think about buybacks, returns to shareholders versus new growth at the company?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, we're just continuing to balance all of the above. We -- as I mentioned, we'll be completing our current share reauthorization here next month. So we'll be taking up that question with the board here very soon. But as you can tell from our outlook,
componenttext: Sure, we're just continuing to balance all of the above. We -- as I mentioned, we'll be completing our current share reauthorization here next month. So we'll be taking up that question with the board here very soon. But as you can tell from our outlook, we're expecting our cash flows to continue to be very healthy this year, and we'll -- and as we've mentioned a number of times, we expect our capital expenditures to be very manageable and we're continuing to be very committed to return value through back to shareholders, through share repurchases and dividends. But you'll just have to stay tuned in terms of what we might do beyond this most recent $200 million accelerated share repurchase.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the only thing that I would add to that very thorough answer is that obviously, free cash flow is a very significant card really dealing with think about all this and we have -- if you believe that our free cash flow is going to continue to grow, we'
componenttext: Yes, the only thing that I would add to that very thorough answer is that obviously, free cash flow is a very significant card really dealing with think about all this and we have -- if you believe that our free cash flow is going to continue to grow, we'll then -- that just gives us more latitude to think about it. Likewise, if you're concerned if free cash flow may go the other way well, then that would influence us also. But it is a very prominent in our thinking and we're next step obviously is to wrap up the existing authorization when we revisit this question with the board.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and the only other comment I would add just to kind of round up the discussion just on our leverage. We've been managing to kind of low to mid-30% range and that -- don't -- we don't really have plans to change that, at least at this juncture.
componenttext: Yes, and the only other comment I would add just to kind of round up the discussion just on our leverage. We've been managing to kind of low to mid-30% range and that -- don't -- we don't really have plans to change that, at least at this juncture.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Julie Yates with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Julie Yates with Credit Suisse.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gary, question on growth. So there's still a lot of growth opportunities for you guys including resurgence to short-haul, international expansion out of Fort Lauderdale and Houston and eventually Hawaii. Just the changed fleet plan impact how you think ab
componenttext: Gary, question on growth. So there's still a lot of growth opportunities for you guys including resurgence to short-haul, international expansion out of Fort Lauderdale and Houston and eventually Hawaii. Just the changed fleet plan impact how you think about prioritizing that growth over the next 2 years?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have to smile, Julie, because Bob Jordan is shaking his head as you're talking about all of these. He's lathering up here and cooling off. I think we had a tactical challenge to work through a step down in the fleet in the third -- late third quarter. N
componenttext: I have to smile, Julie, because Bob Jordan is shaking his head as you're talking about all of these. He's lathering up here and cooling off. I think we had a tactical challenge to work through a step down in the fleet in the third -- late third quarter. Next year, I think is the primary challenge so by the end of the next year, by the end of 2018, we'll be back to our fleet plan and we haven't given you a precise number there yet. So that's a little pea plan it's not etched in stone but we'll work through all of that. In the meantime, it may affect our priority or 2 it's a well premature to say. That's one of the reasons of that we need to give our team this guidance now is because Bob Jordan's commercial team are working right now on what the schedule will be in the fourth quarter of 2017. And it got in no, how many airplanes were going to give them to schedule. So those are questions of it will be immediately thrashed and through. One thing that's a priority for next year that we won't waiver on is Fort Lauderdale, completing the construction of the new international 5-gate terminal and then following through the launch of international flights there. So that will be a very high and hard priority for 2017 that we'll have to potentially work around as one example. But as I've said several times, I think that this is manageable and we can handle it and we'll obviously get to work on it here. But I don't see, Bob, I don't see any change of priority because of that.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is there a timing -- go ahead, Bob.
componenttext: Is there a timing -- go ahead, Bob.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll say though. I agree with Gary. It's tactical. You have a period of time where you have to manage our wants and our needs. A lot of what you mentioned, we're going to always pace our growth here and so some of the things you mentioned are already sort
componenttext: I'll say though. I agree with Gary. It's tactical. You have a period of time where you have to manage our wants and our needs. A lot of what you mentioned, we're going to always pace our growth here and so some of the things you mentioned are already sort of in our sights beyond '18 or beyond anyway. So those really aren't affected because once you get into the mid-to late '18 we're sort of back to what we expected. So it's really just a short-term challenge. It'll be painful, it will definitely be painful.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll have hard decisions and the thing we like in 2016 as a pretty vivid example, the plan that we have for this year did not include any new cities and we will very likely have for as it turned out for 2016 with 3 Cuba cities and Long Beach. So it's nic
componenttext: We'll have hard decisions and the thing we like in 2016 as a pretty vivid example, the plan that we have for this year did not include any new cities and we will very likely have for as it turned out for 2016 with 3 Cuba cities and Long Beach. So it's nice to have that flexibility. Those 4 markets don't require a lot of aircraft time but we did have enough in reserve, where we could jump on those opportunities. So we may have to -- we may have to forego some things like that if they appear during that time period in 2017, 2018 but that -- you get -- we'll be able to manage and I don't think that this really affects our strategy long-term.

componenttext: Well, and Mike can help me here or Bob for that matter, but let me give it a try and see if I'm answering your question if not, please redirect us but our rough estimate with 5 gates assuming that we have access to 5, we have 4 under lease and as long as the fifth is open and available to us, we can use a 5. So the capacity for 5 gates international flying is roughly 25 departures. And I think today where maybe 11, 12 international departures out of Hobby and I'm pretty sure that our folks and at the airport will also use those gates as they need to for domestic flights. So I think if I'm understanding your question, we're where we expected to be by the way if Houston Hobby, not yet a year later. We're just months into operation there. We did not expect to be at capacity that fast, and I know Bob will continue to have Houston as a priority to continue to add international flights there in the future. I can't give you predictions, would not want to give you predictions yet as to when you might be at capacity and the terminal about we'll continue -- we've got plenty of capacity now. It's a great facility. Our customers absolutely love it. And we'll continue to add flights in Houston. Does that respond to your question?

It's a little bit premature.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Yes, the only thing I would add is that because we have a lot of local traffic out of Houston, which is fantastic, we have probably even more flow and connect them we expect which is also fantastic. Fort Lauderdale and Houston, there'll be some synergy with Fort Lauderdale opens because you'll have flight schedules that worked together because it's also a gateway. So you'll have customers that connect over Fort Lauderdale that could potentially have a return flight of that connects over Houston. So it will actually complement each other in terms of the schedule for the purpose of connecting in those airports. So that's a great thing as well. So the Fort Lauderdale will help Houston and Houston will help Fort Lauderdale.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the Classics, how practically do expect to do this. You want to fly them as long as you can before the MAX shows up and have 1 big wave of retirements or should we be thinking about a step down as you get closer?
componenttext: On the Classics, how practically do expect to do this. You want to fly them as long as you can before the MAX shows up and have 1 big wave of retirements or should we be thinking about a step down as you get closer?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no, we have to have every pilot trained to sit in every cockpit. And so it's all or nothing. The way that this has been presented to us. Now we don't know exactly what training requirements Boeing in the FAA and Southwest would ultimately work out but
componenttext: No, no, we have to have every pilot trained to sit in every cockpit. And so it's all or nothing. The way that this has been presented to us. Now we don't know exactly what training requirements Boeing in the FAA and Southwest would ultimately work out but we can't wait that long to develop a training program and then get all of our pilots through it. So no, there'll be a day and one day we'll be flying 50 classics and the next day will be flying 0.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that will be a hard stop.
componenttext: Okay, that will be a hard stop.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it will be a hard stop and so in reference to Julie's earlier question, that's really the task at hand is to figure out how to smoothly do that, and I'm confident we can. It will be painful but we'll try to at least seasonally. It steps down post-Lab
componenttext: Yes, it will be a hard stop and so in reference to Julie's earlier question, that's really the task at hand is to figure out how to smoothly do that, and I'm confident we can. It will be painful but we'll try to at least seasonally. It steps down post-Labor Day. So we have less flying in September than we do early August anyway. So we'll manage it and there'll be a little bit of pain but hopefully we'll be able to contain that, get over it and by a year later, it will all be behind us.

componenttext: Okay. Shifting gears a little bit, Long Beach and also small new city opened, but can you talk a little bit obviously, well established from California, how does Long Beach fit in? Is that somewhere you like to turn into full-size capacity or what happens there?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we're ecstatic to get a foothold into Long Beach here. So we have No avenue for a long time and so just to be able to have a modest schedule to Oakland is great. The airport interacts really well with our other L.A. area service. So I don't
componenttext: Well, I think we're ecstatic to get a foothold into Long Beach here. So we have No avenue for a long time and so just to be able to have a modest schedule to Oakland is great. The airport interacts really well with our other L.A. area service. So I don't think we feel like there'll be cannibalism or anything like that so I think this will really be new traffic for us. We'd love to have more flights over time. I don't think -- I don't see a case where we would add dozens and dozens of but we're going to get another 2, another 4 overtime I think that will be wonderful because I think the traffic is up there or our bookings look good. We're really happy with the traffic build so far and we're looking forward to starting service.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: And you probably know this, David, but we're the #1 airline in the 5 county area among the 4 airports. So I think this will really be awesome. We'll be able to provide more flexibility to customers to go out of one airport and back to another and if we can get more slots, we would love to do that.

componenttext: We're seeing California as strong and we're seeing just general strength on across the network. And as we've called out before, just we have had a high percentage of our markets under development over the last year. So some of those -- the markets that have come on more recently, those are ramping up, now general strength has caused us.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you're referring I guess, to oil and gas, and Houston looks fantastic, Midland looks fantastic. So it's -- our businesses held up quite well. I think it would be fair to say that it's not as strong as it was. But it still really strong. So I feel
componenttext: I think you're referring I guess, to oil and gas, and Houston looks fantastic, Midland looks fantastic. So it's -- our businesses held up quite well. I think it would be fair to say that it's not as strong as it was. But it still really strong. So I feel real good about that. But I agree with Tammy's first reaction, which is it's mostly a function of where we have developing markets. So I think our strength is very, very broad and very consistent across the U.S. and again, we're really pleased. We're pleased with our network. That's been under construction for years and the results look really good. Revenue management has done a phenomenal job in a very competitive environment. And the marketing I think is just -- no one's asked us about it but I think the marketing and the messaging has been absolutely superb presenting Southwest competitive advantages in a very clear and colorful way. And they're going to continue on that course and I think it's going to continue to drive strong revenues for us as well.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gary, you said just 1 minute ago that Houston and Midland are performing I think fantastic was the word you used, right. That seems to be very different from United's experience right now in Houston. So why are you doing well there and they are not? Is it
componenttext: Gary, you said just 1 minute ago that Houston and Midland are performing I think fantastic was the word you used, right. That seems to be very different from United's experience right now in Houston. So why are you doing well there and they are not? Is it a different type of passenger? Or what can you say to explain that?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I -- we don't really compare ourselves to United. First of all, so I don't know that I have an explanation. You might ask United that question. But we have had great success in Houston in particular over the past 4 years as we have been working with
componenttext: Well, I -- we don't really compare ourselves to United. First of all, so I don't know that I have an explanation. You might ask United that question. But we have had great success in Houston in particular over the past 4 years as we have been working with the city to reestablish international service at Houston Hobby. That generated a significant amount of grassroots support locally to convince the city to add that service, which we were very pleased with. What we have discovered at the time when we started this in 2012 is that the airfares, especially internationally out of Bush works extraordinarily high. It doubled, in fact, the airfares compared to even to Chicago in the same airline to point south. So I think what we've been able to do is build a brand-new 5 gate terminal and the city of Houston and the community are very excited about that. We've been able to add a lot of new flights at lower fares and the community has been very excited about that. And our low-cost is such that we can offer that very profitably. We have a decades long business built up in Houston including connecting it to Midland and we just have a real strong franchise in there. We have a lot of loyal customers. We have a lot of Rapid Rewards members so anywhere from 1/3 to 40% of our customers flies on us on Business so I can assure you it's not because we don't have Business customers, we probably carry more business customers in the United States than any other airline. But I would achieve it again to again great service prior to look at what a great network that we offer. We are offering a great product, excellent on-time performance and we really made a very significant investment in the community and I think the community is pleased to know that.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

So I don't know that I can specifically answer when we are going to see our deals turn positive but what we're really focused on of course is our unit revenues and our outlook for unit revenues and out outlook for our revenue is favorable here in the second quarter.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Southwest Airlines First Quarter 2016 Conference Call. My name is Tom, and I'll be moderating today's call. Today's conference is being recorded and a replay will be available on southwest.com in the Investor Relations section.At this tim
componenttext:
Welcome to the Southwest Airlines First Quarter 2016 Conference Call. My name is Tom, and I'll be moderating today's call. Today's conference is being recorded and a replay will be available on southwest.com in the Investor Relations section.
At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to Ms. Marcy Brand, Managing Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, ma'am.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to today's call to discuss our first quarter 2016 results. Joining the call today, we have Gary Kelly, Chairman, President and CEO; Tammy Romo, Executive Vice President and CFO; Bob Jordan, Executive Vic
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to today's call to discuss our first quarter 2016 results. Joining the call today, we have Gary Kelly, Chairman, President and CEO; Tammy Romo, Executive Vice President and CFO; Bob Jordan, Executive Vice President and Chief Commercial Officer; and Mike Van De Ven, Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer.
Please note today's call will include forward-looking statements, and because these statements are based on the company's current intent, expectations and projections, they are not guarantees of future performance and a variety of factors could cause actual results to differ materially.
As this call will include references to non-GAAP results, excluding special items, please reference this morning's press release in the Investor Relations section at southwest.com for further information regarding forward-looking statements and reconciliations of non-GAAP results to GAAP results.
At this time, I'd like to go ahead and turn the call over to Gary for opening remarks.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Marcy, and good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our first quarter earnings call. We are absolutely delighted with these results and considering the quality of our operation, the hospitality of our customer service and these strong
componenttext:
Thank you, Marcy, and good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our first quarter earnings call. We are absolutely delighted with these results and considering the quality of our operation, the hospitality of our customer service and these strong profits, it is absolutely the best start we've had to a year and over 2 decades so I'm very, very pleased.
Of course, a big driver in our 33% earnings per share growth is a lower jet fuel price but the revenue performance was also superb. This year is essentially the follow through to a healthy expansion that began back in 2014 with the repeal of the Wright Amendment and then the aggressive expansion out of Dallas Love Field and that was followed by the integration and conversion of AirTran at year-end 2014 and that generated a lot of new flights in Southwest as well. Following the AirTran conversion, we launched 4 new international cities in 2015 as well as a new terminal and domestic gateway at Houston Hobby. So you add all that up and that's a 9.2% capacity growth here in the first quarter. Would certainly admit that that is a lot, and what is impressive is that our revenue growth kept pace. So we continue to experience outstanding performance out of Dallas Love Field. The rest of our developing markets are providing a very nice tailwind as well as they continue along an expected maturity path.
Last year at this time, we had about 20% of our system in development, and this year because we have intentionally slowed the additions of new markets, we have only about 5% in development.
And of course, as a backdrop, the industry is adding fleets aggressively. It's a very competitive environment. Of course, that's all fine with us. We have low cost, and we have a great low fare brand but we've been very pleased with a consistent strong demand for the Southwest product, resulting in yet another record load factor in the first quarter and numerous other records for that matter. But the point is even in the face of our growth and the intensely-competitive environment, we're doing really, really well.
And I would attribute that to a couple of things. First and foremost, to our people and the terrific service that they offer our customers every single day. I'm very proud of them and of course, I congratulate them on these great results and the record profit sharing that they've earned. I also attribute our results to our strong domestic network, where we offer more seats and board more customers than any other airline.
Our marketing department, in particular, has done a terrific job of distilling our message with our advertising campaign on transparency, the customer awareness of the low fare value that you get with Southwest is very high and that timing of that campaign matches perfectly with the incredible momentum that we have had with our record rewards loyalty program. So we have a strong profitable network. We have great service, low fares with nothing to hide. We have an award-winning loyalty program and all of that served up by outstanding employees. So we are exceptionally well positioned to compete and grow, and we intend to keep it just that way.
Now before I turn it over to Tammy, I have noticed in some of the reports this morning, a little bit of confusion, so I did want to make an opening clarifying point, which is with the now, earlier retirement of our classic fleet. I just want to be sure that everyone understands that what we said in our press release is that means that the growth rate will be less, not that our capacity will be less. So we will still grow, available seat miles under any scenario that we contemplated in 2017 compared to 2016 and then the same would be true also for 2018 as compared to 2017. The point is that the growth rates in '17 will no doubt be less than it should have been.
So Tammy, with those opening remarks, let me just turn it over to you to take us through the quarter. Please, ma'am.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gary, and welcome, everyone. We're thrilled to report on our exceptionally strong first quarter results. Net income, excluding special items, increased almost 26% year-over-year to a record $567 million and earnings per share grew 33%. This repres
componenttext:
Thanks, Gary, and welcome, everyone. We're thrilled to report on our exceptionally strong first quarter results. Net income, excluding special items, increased almost 26% year-over-year to a record $567 million and earnings per share grew 33%. This represented our 12th consecutive quarter of record profit. Our revenue results remained at record levels, and we continue to benefit from low fuel prices and our ongoing fleet modernization efforts. We expanded our operating margin, excluding special items to 19.7%, which is the highest it's been in more than 35 years and our pretax return on invested capital, excluding special items for the 12 months ended March 2016, was 33.4%, which well exceeded our cost of capital on a after-tax basis.
Just a fantastic start to the year, and I'd also like to congratulate our wonderful employees on these outstanding results and their record first quarter profit sharing of $155 million.
Our strong revenue performance in first quarter was a significant driver of our record first quarter earnings. Operating revenues grew to a record $4.8 billion and our passenger revenues also grew to record levels. Strong demand for our low friendly fares and the overall strength of our network were contributing factors to our 9.3% increase in revenues.
We're pleased with the performance of our development markets that resulted in about a point net tailwind to RASM in first quarter. International markets also performed in line with our expectations, including our new Houston markets and Dallas continues to produce solid results with load factor expansion and strong margins in first quarter.
Our Rapid Rewards revenue production was very strong in the quarter, including approximately $125 million, a year-over-year incremental revenue from our amended co-brand agreement with Chase last July, and our ancillary revenues continued to perform very well.
Our revenue growth was in line with our capacity, resulting in flat RASM, which was industry leading and notable, considering the 1- to 2-point impact from our stage engage increase in first quarter. All around, very pleased with our first quarter revenue performance.
While the weak yield environment has continued into second quarter, demand so far has remained solid and based on our current bookings and revenue trends, we are expecting a modest growth in second quarter, 2016 RASM performance year-over-year. And just as a reminder again, this outlook includes roughly $125 million from the Chase agreement and accounting change that -- just as a reminder that we will lapse that year-over-year benefit in the third quarter.
Our freight revenue was down slightly year-over-year and other revenue production was boosted by the Chase agreement, but also by a 12% increase in ancillary revenues, mostly from growth in EarlyBird and our upgraded boarding product. We currently expect second quarter 2016 freight and other revenues to increase from second quarter last year.
Turning to our cost. We are very pleased with our first quarter cost performance. Our operating unit cost, excluding special items, decreased 2.6% year-over-year from ongoing fleet modernization benefits amount to weather and lower jet fuel prices. Our economic fuel price per gallon declined 11% year-over-year to $1.78. This year-over-year decline was driven primarily by lower crude and heating oil prices, offset by higher hedging settlements year-over-year. We ended up a little higher than our previous guide at the beginning of March, simply due to the increase in the crude and heating oil since that time. And based on market prices as of Monday and our second quarter hedge, that remains unchanged. We currently expect our fuel price per gallon to be in the $1.75 to $1.80 range. And for full year 2016, we currently expect to fall in the $1.85 to $1.90 range based on current market prices.
Excluding fuel and special items, our unit cost were comparable to first quarter last year, and down slightly when you also include -- excuse me, exclude profit sharing. This was better than our previous guidance due to milder weather and associated costs avoided as well as ship to projects spend to later this year.
Based on our current cost trends, we expect second quarter 2016 CASM, excluding fuel special items to profit sharing to increase approximately 2% year-over-year. And roughly 1 point of the year-over-year increase is driven by accelerated depreciation from our Classics retirement. And the remainder of the cost inflation is largely as a result of timing of advertising and technology investments.
For our -- for the full year 2016, we continue to estimate a modest 1% increase in our unit costs, excluding fuel, special items and profit sharing, which again is driven entirely by the accelerated depreciation.
Our balance sheet and cash flows remain very strong and our cash and short-term investments were $3.6 billion at the end of the quarter. We allowed our cash to build a bit as we plan to fund our 2015 profit-sharing accrual later this month, and we also intend to launch a $200 million accelerated share repurchase, which will be completed next month.
Our record free cash flow was $1.2 billion as a result of strong operating cash flow of $1.6 billion and $438 million of capital spend. For our full year 2016, we continue to estimate manageable CapEx of approximately $2 billion.
We returned $596 million to shareholders in share repurchases and dividends in the first quarter and as I previously mentioned, we will be launching a $200 million accelerated share repurchase this month to complete our current $1.5 billion repurchase authorization, and this was on the heels of returning $1.4 billion to our shareholders in 2015. Returning significant value to our shareholders remains a priority along with preserving the strength of our balance sheet and cash flows.
Our leverage, including balance sheet aircraft leases, remains in the low to mid-30% range, and we are very proud of our strong balance sheet and we remain the only domestic airline with an investment grade rating from all 3 rating agencies.
So before I wrap up, I'd like to spend just a little bit of time going over our announcement this morning regarding our Classics retirement fleet plans. So as you will recall in January, we announced our intent to retire our Classics fleet no later than mid-2018. Earlier this month, we made the decision to refine the acceleration date to no later than third quarter 2017 to allow for our Classics fleet to be retired ahead of our planned operating date of the Boeing -800 Max aircraft. By doing so, we'll alleviate the potential training complexities related to operating both the Classics and MAX aircraft. Boeing and FAA aren't expected to determine their training requirements of operating the Classics/Max pair until May of 2017 at the earliest, which doesn't allow adequate time to be trained and operationally ready for a 2017 MAX launch. So our preference to address the undefined FAA requirement was to segment, Classics and MAX flying. We've been working with the swap and negotiating team to come up with a mutually beneficial solution to address the segmentation but unfortunately, we've been able to come to any agreement.
So in order to move forward with our plan to watch the launch of MAX, we must proceed with the solution, which retiring our Classics fleet no later than third quarter '17 provides.
So as a result of this decision, we'll have about 50 fewer aircraft than previously planned in fourth quarter 2017, which obviously also creates less capacity. And again as Gary mentioned, we intend to have capacity growth but just this decision alone creates less capacity than what we had previously planned.
That said, we're evaluating our options given these circumstances and believe, we have a lot of flexibility to manage through the temporary dip in our fleet as we did with the 717s, including utilization of our fleets.
So with that in mind, we continue to expect our year-over-year fleet growth for the 3 years ended 2018 to average no more than 2% and again, our annual year-over-year capacity over that period is still expected to peak this year at 5% to 6%. While we'll continue to evaluate our fleet plans based on where we are today, our aircraft CapEx forecast remains in the $1.3 billion to $1.4 billion range for this year.
And while I mentioned that before, our preference for a number of reasons would have been to segment our fleet, however, we still estimate even improvement of at least $200 million from accelerating the Classics from the 2021 time frame to 2017, again largely driven by maintenance and fuel savings. This is net of the impact of the estimated accelerated depreciation of approximately $130 million that will largely be expensed during 2016. And of course, accelerating our Classics retirement results in an improved customer service even faster, with a fully equipped Wi-Fi suite by the end of third quarter of next year.
So with regards to capacity just again, to be clear we continue to plan for 5% to 6% year-over-year growth this year. Our second and third quarter ASMs will increase in the 4% to 5% range, and we will be publishing our fourth quarter schedule in May, which will go through January 4 of next year. And as we've noted previously, the majority of 2016 capacity growth is related to the annualized impact of 2015 unit expansion opportunities. While our capacity plans beyond 2016 are yet to be determined, we do expect 2017 and 2018 year-over-year ASM growth to bend down from 2016's level. We will remain disciplined in our approach to growth, with a focus of flexibility to adjust if needed and with a goal to preserve strong returns and margins.
So in conclusion, we had another record quarter, with or without the benefit of substantially lower fuel prices, our earnings and margins improved year-over-year. Demand remained strong, producing record revenues and our outlook for second quarter suggests positive operating unit revenue growth. Our cost outlook for the year is for modest inflation, driven largely by our decision to accelerate the retirement of the Classics fleet even faster than we'd previously announced, which is expected to produce significant cost savings and even improvement of at least $200 million.
Fuel prices remain lower year-over-year, and we have had very strong free cash flow this year and our balance sheet is strong as ever. We've continued our commitment to reach our value to shareholders, and intend to complete our current authorization with the launch of a $200 million ASR by the end of this month, and we will continue to prudently manage our capital spend and we'll remain disciplined in our evaluation of future growth opportunities.
Again, our pretax return on invested capital was an exceptional 33.4%. Our outlook for second quarter supports another quarter of strong margins, likely in excess of first quarters of 19.7% and with that, I'd like to close by thanking our employees again for another fantastic quarter.
So Tom, we'll be happy to open it up for questions now.
