headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rajeev, I'd be happy to start with your question regarding RASM trends. So I'll just walk you through the quarter a bit. So just at the highest level, January and February RASM were slightly down and then March was slightly up, which got us to the roughly
componenttext: Rajeev, I'd be happy to start with your question regarding RASM trends. So I'll just walk you through the quarter a bit. So just at the highest level, January and February RASM were slightly down and then March was slightly up, which got us to the roughly flat unit revenue comparison with about $15 million of benefit from Easter in March. So April, we're at RASM adjusted for Easter is currently running in line with March and as you think about the comparisons as we move forward in the quarter, we expect that to improve as a result of the increased competitive environment that we began experiencing in May and June of last year. And then of course, as a reminder again, we'll continue to have the year-over-year benefit from the Chase agreement, at least through the second quarter here. So again, I think we're positioned very well here as we start second quarter and I would just characterize the demand environment as solid. And so at this point, adjust the -- we're continuing to see the same sort of trends that we saw in the first quarter.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: What about just the rest of the year and keeping that trend going, especially with the Chase agreement I think?
componenttext: What about just the rest of the year and keeping that trend going, especially with the Chase agreement I think?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's the one. It's always hard to predict further out in the year. Certainly, we're off to a good start here in the second quarter and as you pointed out, the comparisons do become more difficult in the second half because we lapsed the benefit
componenttext: I think that's the one. It's always hard to predict further out in the year. Certainly, we're off to a good start here in the second quarter and as you pointed out, the comparisons do become more difficult in the second half because we lapsed the benefit of the Chase agreement.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I might take up the -- unless you have any more questions on that, Rajeev, I might take up the fleet question for a second. I think it is the usual suspects that are available to us. We can tweak the utilization of the aircraft, which translates to a l
componenttext: So I might take up the -- unless you have any more questions on that, Rajeev, I might take up the fleet question for a second. I think it is the usual suspects that are available to us. We can tweak the utilization of the aircraft, which translates to a longer duty day of the airplane. I'm not sure that that's what we want to do, but that is an option. In other words, just flying later, earlier and later in the day. We can search the used market for more 700s, and we have some options as you know by our fleet chart. We have options that can be exercised as well, which would translate to more -- to be clear, that would be more capital spending. That's not in Tammy's capital spending guidance that -- in other words, the capital spending guidance does not assume the exercise of any options, to be clear. In no scenario that we've talked about would we bring in 50 more airplanes. And Mike, I don't recall exactly how many aircraft would be ultimately retired under the previous scenario, but I'm going to guess it was around 30 that would have been retired in one step, 30-ish. So the 50 is not quite as large as it might sound although again that's a real number but we were already going to retire a fair number of aircraft in 2018. So as I said in the press release, this is all manageable. It's not preferable, but it's all manageable. And we're just not -- the first thing that we wanted to share with all of our team and of course, you all as well is if that is going to happen, that being the Classic retirement acceleration. Now the company can go to work on translating that into maintenance programs for that fleet to now retire earlier. That will avoid some maintenance spending as Tammy has already made clear. And then we can explore other options as far as bringing either leased equipment in or exercising some options and spending a little bit more capital. But I think the other thing just to make sure that everybody is clear in their head on is that we -- our projected fleet at the end of 2018 is unaffected by any of this. So you're simply talking about accelerating retirements from 2018 into 2017. And that makes this all for us a little bit easier. And another reason why we want to be thoughtful about bringing on more airplanes to replace that, so all of that is still an open question. And as soon as we make some choices there, I'm sure we'll be sharing those.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Jamie Baker with JPMorgan.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Jamie Baker with JPMorgan.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gary, on the topic of the Classics, is the decision potentially reversible, and how much lead time would you need if you did negotiate a solution to keep these airplanes in the fourth quarter of '17? I'm trying to assess at lower capacity is a done deal h
componenttext: Gary, on the topic of the Classics, is the decision potentially reversible, and how much lead time would you need if you did negotiate a solution to keep these airplanes in the fourth quarter of '17? I'm trying to assess at lower capacity is a done deal here, or if this is merely a shot across, swap that could be revisited at the negotiating table?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I read your note earlier so I'm glad you asked me the question because one thing I want to clarify is this is not a shot, contrary to the way our industry is worked with employees in the past. That's not the way we do business here at Southwest
componenttext: Yes. Well, I read your note earlier so I'm glad you asked me the question because one thing I want to clarify is this is not a shot, contrary to the way our industry is worked with employees in the past. That's not the way we do business here at Southwest so...

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, duly noted.
componenttext: Okay, duly noted.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The -- well, and it's -- you know that. I just wanted to be sure that all of our listeners know that, but that's not what this is about. We're here to take care of our people and clearly accelerating this retirement is not going to be a good thing for our
componenttext: The -- well, and it's -- you know that. I just wanted to be sure that all of our listeners know that, but that's not what this is about. We're here to take care of our people and clearly accelerating this retirement is not going to be a good thing for our employees. It's not a bad thing, but we're not at war with our people. We're at war with our competitors, number one. On -- with respect to whether it is negotiable, well, in that spirit, of course, we want to continue to work with the pilots union in particular to do what we can to keep our cost competitive and grow this airline so that we can be as competitive as possible. I don't realistically see a scenario, Mike, where we can -- I mean, that's why we're sharing this today. It's not so much that it is a decision. I don't see that we have any choice because we have to begin to put plans into effect for training, maintenance and then if we are going to go out and try to mitigate the earlier retirement, we've got to be working on that and I'm sure that sooner than later,  we'll want to make commitments there. So as a practical matter, I think that's a done deal and I just -- to be blunt, I just don't see swap moving on their position regarding segmentation. So as a practical matter I think it's a done deal.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I appreciate the color. On the topic of the pilot -- on the topic of the swap and the pilot offer from last month, it did look pretty rich to us represented over 2 points of CASM by our analysis and again that's just the pilots all in. It's getting
componenttext: Okay, I appreciate the color. On the topic of the pilot -- on the topic of the swap and the pilot offer from last month, it did look pretty rich to us represented over 2 points of CASM by our analysis and again that's just the pilots all in. It's getting hard to imagine how the entirety of your new contracts won't increase x-fuel CASM by 4 points, possibly more if it was rolled up into a single year. What assurances, Gary, can you give us that you possess sufficient revenue initiatives that can offset this cost pressure? Or do we just have to assume that that post-labor, Southwest will have lower, still very good but lower margins than today on a fuel-neutral basis?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, great questions. Obviously, it is very important for us to maintain our low fare brand and our low fare brand is not negotiable. In order to have a business in a low fare brand, we have to have that supported by low costs. So that's what the company
componenttext: Well, great questions. Obviously, it is very important for us to maintain our low fare brand and our low fare brand is not negotiable. In order to have a business in a low fare brand, we have to have that supported by low costs. So that's what the company was founded on 45 years ago, and we're certainly not going to reiterate that. All these negotiations they're complex, they take a long time and especially in light of the fact that we are in mediation, where the mediator has asked us to maintain confidentiality about what is discussed. I know you don't expect me to go into any detail but I certainly want to honor that request for confidentiality. But all of these just has to be addressed at the negotiating table with an eye towards rewarding our people and compensating them handsomely, but doing that in a way where we maintain industry-leading productivity and efficiency so that we sustain our low-cost structure. So what I can give you assurance on is that we have not wavered in our desire to achieve that goal. And we'll have to continue to work together with our union leadership to be able to live up to that.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Hunter Keay with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Hunter Keay with Wolfe Research.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Gary, or maybe Bob, if you're there too, when you think about the heavy mix of connecting traffic at Love Field, even more specifically on the Wright Amendment routes being so high, like well above 40% I think. It looks like you may have sort of inadve
componenttext: So Gary, or maybe Bob, if you're there too, when you think about the heavy mix of connecting traffic at Love Field, even more specifically on the Wright Amendment routes being so high, like well above 40% I think. It looks like you may have sort of inadvertently created a bit of a rolling hub there. So thinking about that in the context of the new market development, how satisfied are you right now with your ability to manage yields in Dallas, on an O&D basis given all those connections? And is that an opportunity that is sort of new for you guys that maybe has a little bit of underappreciated upside that even you yourself aren't able to quantify right now?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm going to let Bob speak to that as well. And he is here. He is sitting right by me. The -- no, actually, I feel like the Dallas Love Field operation is pretty much in line with what I would have expected except as I admitted to you all before, th
componenttext: Well, I'm going to let Bob speak to that as well. And he is here. He is sitting right by me. The -- no, actually, I feel like the Dallas Love Field operation is pretty much in line with what I would have expected except as I admitted to you all before, the rapid development of those markets and the full flights actually took me a little bit by surprise. I thought it would take us a while longer to produce the kind of results we have there. Tammy, I did glance this morning earlier, the returns out of Dallas are still right at system average, maybe just a hair below for the first quarter. So simply meaning, Hunter, that it is -- I would not call Dallas in development. Clearly Bob, is going to disagree and say there are certain markets that he wants to better performance, but overall as an entity, it looks really good. I've never noticed any remarkable difference in the O&D mix versus connects -- Dallas versus any other place. Sounds like you've been studying this, but as our intent would be to have Chicago, St. Louis, Phoenix, Baltimore -- all of those very large operation -- Houston, all of those very large operations look roughly the same. And I don't -- I'm not seeing anything that says that it is remarkably different. And I certainly haven't seen anything so far to suggest that there is any disappointment whatsoever in Dallas.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no. Hunter, this is Bob, and thanks for the question. I think a couple of things. Our Dallas performance is right in line with the system as Gary said. Now we built Dallas up in a serious sort of tranches of adding flights. And so some groupings of fl
componenttext: No, no. Hunter, this is Bob, and thanks for the question. I think a couple of things. Our Dallas performance is right in line with the system as Gary said. Now we built Dallas up in a serious sort of tranches of adding flights. And so some groupings of flights are more mature than others. So I'll say that the last couple of groupings that we added, which are obviously younger are continuing to develop and we'll see that, I'm confident over time. So there's still room for improvement in Dallas even though it is right at system average. From the traffic mix, just because Dallas is constrained, always remember, we would love to have more flights in Dallas than we can have and so because of that, we're always going to bias for local traffic more than we would in an unconstrained large city like a Chicago for example. So we do -- because we could have more capacity in Dallas, Dallas will always I think slightly underweight the flow and connect traffic compared to what it could be if we were not constrained because we've got to make room for local traffic, which again there's more local traffic demand than we have room for at the gates and flights that we have in Dallas.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hunter, the only thing I would add to what we both said is that we're conscious of this. We -- there are some analogies to Love Field around the country that I won't mention, but we do have techniques where we can influence one way or the other. So we're
componenttext: Hunter, the only thing I would add to what we both said is that we're conscious of this. We -- there are some analogies to Love Field around the country that I won't mention, but we do have techniques where we can influence one way or the other. So we're very happy with the way Dallas is performing. Again, it's a constrained market as we know, so we'll have to continue to keep an eye on it. But I don't know if we're hitting the point on your question or not.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I know it's -- we can maybe take this off-line. I want to ask another question, so that's good enough for now. And then if I back out the $125 million credit card benefit, it looks like unless some stuff moved around to the P&L which I'm not aware, l
componenttext: Yes, I know it's -- we can maybe take this off-line. I want to ask another question, so that's good enough for now. And then if I back out the $125 million credit card benefit, it looks like unless some stuff moved around to the P&L which I'm not aware, looks like your other revenue group up 35%. The first is, is that right? And if so what is that? Tammy mentioned earlier EarlyBird up whatever 12% and once we lap the credit card, how should we think about that other revenue growth rate in the third quarter and beyond? Because again, well, I'm just curious if my -- first of all correct my underlying math and how should we think about beyond once we lapped the credit card?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Hunter, I can -- I'll be happy to help with that. Yes, we are seeing strong growth in our other. The -- just as a reminder of our -- just so you know, where the components of the benefit from our credit card fall if you -- the net is the $124 million
componenttext: Yes, Hunter, I can -- I'll be happy to help with that. Yes, we are seeing strong growth in our other. The -- just as a reminder of our -- just so you know, where the components of the benefit from our credit card fall if you -- the net is the $124 million and other revenues were increased by about call it $175 million and passenger revenues decreased by about $50 million. So the -- so I'm not sure if you did your math exactly right there, but that's the split of the net, 100 and -- roughly $125 million benefit from Chase. But we're continuing to see strong ancillary revenues. We had a strong EarlyBird revenues and -- but again, and aside...

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have more bag fees, we have more WiFi. We have more pets, we have -- the others are collection that your -- I can't attest to your math either, but I am certain that we had a very strong growth in the core group of ancillary revenues.
componenttext: Well, we have more bag fees, we have more WiFi. We have more pets, we have -- the others are collection that your -- I can't attest to your math either, but I am certain that we had a very strong growth in the core group of ancillary revenues.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So yes just...
componenttext: Yes. So yes just...

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would think -- I think your question was, should that continue, Tammy, I would think you would continue to see that?
componenttext: And I would think -- I think your question was, should that continue, Tammy, I would think you would continue to see that?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think so again just with the caveat, of course, that will lapse the benefit of the Chase been on July -- in July.
componenttext: I think so again just with the caveat, of course, that will lapse the benefit of the Chase been on July -- in July.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Andrew Didora with Bank of America.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Andrew Didora with Bank of America.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, Gary, you spoke about this in your prepared remarks but one of the reasons you have been posting industry-leading revenues of late has been the maturation of many of your routes. As you look at the impact over the course of the year, do you think
componenttext: I guess, Gary, you spoke about this in your prepared remarks but one of the reasons you have been posting industry-leading revenues of late has been the maturation of many of your routes. As you look at the impact over the course of the year, do you think this maturation is having a bigger impact on revenues today, or call it the first half of the year? Or do you think this accelerates into the back half of the year? I guess any color you can provide around the timing of that would be helpful.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It feels like it will trend away from us. So in other words, it's higher today than it should be a year from now. I also think that there's quite a bit of artwork that we're debating internally about how to define a development market. So we're seeing rea
componenttext: It feels like it will trend away from us. So in other words, it's higher today than it should be a year from now. I also think that there's quite a bit of artwork that we're debating internally about how to define a development market. So we're seeing really broad strength in our cities and Bob, I don't think we call an additional frequency in the market that's existing. We don't call that "Development" So I think the impact is likely larger than the point that Tammy shared with you. I think all of our folks agree with that. So we maybe a little bit conservative and that may be a conservative outlook as a consequence of that. But the other thing is not only is the existing maturing, but we're also slowing down the pace of stepping in new and that's all intentional. So we'll have a pretty conservative year in 2016 in terms of incremental flying that's being added between now and the end of the year, and that will help as well. So the tailwind should exist all year long, and I think it will begin to diminish roughly a year from now.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's very helpful. And also just wanted to touch upon the balance sheet and capital returns. I guess with no change right now in terms of your CapEx spend, do you think we could see a pickup in the pace of buybacks particularly as I guess fuel sta
componenttext: Okay, that's very helpful. And also just wanted to touch upon the balance sheet and capital returns. I guess with no change right now in terms of your CapEx spend, do you think we could see a pickup in the pace of buybacks particularly as I guess fuel stays lower, a little bit lower for longer now. I guess maybe any color you can provide in terms of how you think about buybacks, returns to shareholders versus new growth at the company?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, we are just continuing to balance all of the above. We -- as I mentioned, we'll be completing our current share reauthorization here next month. So we'll be taking up that question with the board here very soon. But as you can tell from our outlook,
componenttext: Sure, we are just continuing to balance all of the above. We -- as I mentioned, we'll be completing our current share reauthorization here next month. So we'll be taking up that question with the board here very soon. But as you can tell from our outlook, we're expecting our cash flows to continue to be very healthy this year, and we'll -- and as we mentioned a number of times, we expect our capital expenditures to be very manageable and we're continuing to be very committed to return value through back to our shareholders, through share repurchases and dividends. But you'll just have to stay tuned in terms of what we might do beyond this most recent $200 million accelerated share repurchase.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the only thing that I would add to that very thorough answer is that obviously, free cash flow is a very significant guardrail in the way we think about all this, and if one -- if you believe that our free cash flow is going to continue to grow, we'l
componenttext: Yes, the only thing that I would add to that very thorough answer is that obviously, free cash flow is a very significant guardrail in the way we think about all this, and if one -- if you believe that our free cash flow is going to continue to grow, we'll then -- that just gives us more latitude to think about it. Likewise, if you're concerned that free cash flow may go the other way well, then that would influence us also. But it is very prominent in our thinking and we're -- the next step obviously is to wrap up the existing authorization and we'll revisit this question with the board.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and just the only other comment I would add just to kind of round up the discussion is just on our leverage. We've been managing to kind of low to mid-30% range and that -- don't -- we don't really have any plans to change that, at least at this junc
componenttext: Yes, and just the only other comment I would add just to kind of round up the discussion is just on our leverage. We've been managing to kind of low to mid-30% range and that -- don't -- we don't really have any plans to change that, at least at this juncture.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Julie Yates with Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Julie Yates with Crdit Suisse.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gary, a question on growth. So there's still a lot of growth opportunity for you guys including resurgence to shorthaul, international expansion out of Fort Lauderdale and Houston and eventually Hawaii. Does the changed fleet plan impact how you think abo
componenttext: Gary, a question on growth. So there's still a lot of growth opportunity for you guys including resurgence to shorthaul, international expansion out of Fort Lauderdale and Houston and eventually Hawaii. Does the changed fleet plan impact how you think about prioritizing that growth over the next 2 years?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have to smile, Julie, because Bob Jordan is shaking his head as you're talking about all of these opportunities. He's lathering up here and cooling off. I think we have a tactical challenge to work through a step down in the fleet in the third -- late t
componenttext: I have to smile, Julie, because Bob Jordan is shaking his head as you're talking about all of these opportunities. He's lathering up here and cooling off. I think we have a tactical challenge to work through a step down in the fleet in the third -- late third quarter next year, I think, is the primary challenge. So by the end of the next year, by the end of 2018, we'll be back to our fleet plan, and we haven't given you a precise number there yet. So that's a little pea plan. It's not etched in stone but we'll work through all of that. In the meantime, it may affect a priority or 2. It's a little premature to say. That's one of the reasons that we need to give our team this guidance now is because Bob Jordan and his commercial team are working right now on what the schedule will be in the fourth quarter of 2017. And they've got to know how many airplanes we're going to give them to schedule. So those are questions that will be immediately thrashing through. One thing that's a priority for next year that we won't waiver on is Fort Lauderdale, completing the construction of the new international 5-gate terminal and then following through to launch international flights there. So that will be a very high and hard priority for 2017 that we'll have to potentially work around is one example. But as I've said several times, I think that this is manageable, and we can handle it and we'll obviously get to work on it here. But I don't see any -- Bob, I don't see any change in priority because of that.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Is there a timing -- go ahead, Bob.
componenttext: Okay. Is there a timing -- go ahead, Bob.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Obviously, I don't know them. I agree with Gary. It's just -- it's tactical. You got a period of time where you have to manage our wants and our needs. A lot of what you mentioned, we're going to always pace our growth here. And so some of the things you
componenttext: Obviously, I don't know them. I agree with Gary. It's just -- it's tactical. You got a period of time where you have to manage our wants and our needs. A lot of what you mentioned, we're going to always pace our growth here. And so some of the things you mentioned are already sort of in our sights beyond -- '18 or beyond anyway. So those are really unaffected because once you get into the mid to late '18, we're sort of back to where we expected. So it's really just a short-term challenge. It'll be painful, it will definitely be painful.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we'll have hard decisions, and the thing that we've liked here in 2016 has a pretty vivid example. The plan that we have for this year did not include any new cities, and we will very likely have 4 as it turned out for 2016, with 3 Cuba cities and Lo
componenttext: Yes, we'll have hard decisions, and the thing that we've liked here in 2016 has a pretty vivid example. The plan that we have for this year did not include any new cities, and we will very likely have 4 as it turned out for 2016, with 3 Cuba cities and Long Beach. So it's nice to have that flexibility. Those 4 markets don't require a lot of aircraft time, but we did have enough in reserve where we could jump on those opportunities. So we may have to -- we may have to forego some things like that, if they appear during that time period in 2017, 2018 but that -- again, we'll be able to manage and I don't think that this really impacts our strategy in long term.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Gary, can you just remind us the timing on the expansion out of Fort Lauderdale? Or if there's any update on the construction of the new facility?
componenttext: Okay. Gary, can you just remind us the timing on the expansion out of Fort Lauderdale? Or if there's any update on the construction of the new facility?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't believe we have any new updates. It's first half of next year. I think -- a decent assumption I think that we've been sharing publicly is midyear, but we don't have a precise date yet.
componenttext: I don't believe we have any new updates. It's first half of next year. I think -- a decent assumption I think that we've been sharing publicly is midyear, but we don't have a precise date yet.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Savi Syth with Raymond James.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Savi Syth with Raymond James.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask about Houston as -- since the international gates opened there. I have been a little surprised that I think there maybe 10 daily -- up to 10 daily flights out of Houston internationally. I was wondering how many gates you're using the
componenttext: I just wanted to ask about Houston as -- since the international gates opened there. I have been a little surprised that I think there maybe 10 daily -- up to 10 daily flights out of Houston internationally. I was wondering how many gates you're using there? And what the plan is? And maybe what that -- what similarities we might have as you -- as we think about the growth out of Fort Lauderdale international?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, and Mike can help me here or Bob for that matter. Let me give it a try and see if I'm answering your question. If not, please redirect this. But our rough estimate with 5 gates, assuming that we have access to 5, we have 4 under lease and as long as
componenttext: Well, and Mike can help me here or Bob for that matter. Let me give it a try and see if I'm answering your question. If not, please redirect this. But our rough estimate with 5 gates, assuming that we have access to 5, we have 4 under lease and as long as the fifth is open and available to us, we can use 5. So the capacity for 5 gates international flying is roughly 25 departures. And I think today where maybe 11, 12 international departures out of Hobby, and I'm pretty sure that our folks at the airport will also use those gates as they need to for domestic flights. So I think if I'm understanding your question, we're where we expected to be, by the way, at Houston Hobby, we're not yet a year later. We're just months into operation there. We did not expect to be at capacity that fast, and I know Bob will continue to have Houston as a priority to continue to add international flights there in the future. I can't give you prediction or -- and would not want to give you prediction yet as to when we might be at capacity in the terminal, but we'll continue -- we've got plenty of capacity now. It's a great facility. Our customers absolutely love it, and we'll continue to add flights in Houston. Is that responsive to your question?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's exactly what I was looking for.
componenttext: That's exactly what I was looking for.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fort Lauderdale, I think, again, it's a little bit premature to tell you exactly what our plans are, but they're not dissimilar from what I've described, at least in concept. It's another 5-gate facility. Bob, off the top of my head, I don't recall exactl
componenttext: Fort Lauderdale, I think, again, it's a little bit premature to tell you exactly what our plans are, but they're not dissimilar from what I've described, at least in concept. It's another 5-gate facility. Bob, off the top of my head, I don't recall exactly how many gates we have access to. I believe it's all 5.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's all 5, yes.
componenttext: It's all 5, yes.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think it's the same scenario as we have in Houston. So I'm going to guess that we have roughly the same kind of 25 departure day kind of capacity there. And now Cuba, assuming that all gets approved, our request is to add flights out of Fort Lauderd
componenttext: And I think it's the same scenario as we have in Houston. So I'm going to guess that we have roughly the same kind of 25 departure day kind of capacity there. And now Cuba, assuming that all gets approved, our request is to add flights out of Fort Lauderdale. So if we start Cuba flying this year, we'll already have some international flights, even before the terminal opens, which was in our original plan but -- so Fort Lauderdale could ramp up faster than Houston has, I just don't know yet. It's a little bit premature to say.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the only thing to add is the because they -- we have a lot of local traffic out of Houston, which is fantastic, we have probably even more flow and connect them we expected, which is also fantastic. So we're really happy. It's right on what we expect
componenttext: Yes, the only thing to add is the because they -- we have a lot of local traffic out of Houston, which is fantastic, we have probably even more flow and connect them we expected, which is also fantastic. So we're really happy. It's right on what we expected. Fort Lauderdale and Houston, there'll be some synergy when Fort Lauderdale opens because you'll have flight schedules that worked together because it's also a gateway. So you'll have customers that connect over Fort Lauderdale that could potentially have a return flight that connects over Houston. So they'll actually complement each other in terms of the schedule for folks who are connecting in those airports. So that's a great thing as well. So the Fort Lauderdale will help Houston, and Houston will help Fort Lauderdale.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: As I look at your cash flow estimate, Tammy, you've got air traffic liability declining on a year-on-year basis from $717 last March to $685 this March, and you've got 5.5% more capacity growth. Should I be worried about that decline?

componenttext: No, not at all, Helane. So there's no concerns. componenttext: I don't think so. Hey, it's a very competitive environment, and I'm very pleased with our results, and especially in light of that. But I don't -- I will say, I think, Tammy that consistent with what we're reporting on today, which are booking trends and revenue trends for April, there's no -- there's nothing new to report there. So the trends are continuing. Not better, not worse.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the Classics, how practically do you expect to do this. You want to fly them as long as you can before the MAX shows up and have one big wave of retirements or should we be thinking about a step down as you get closer?
componenttext: On the Classics, how practically do you expect to do this. You want to fly them as long as you can before the MAX shows up and have one big wave of retirements or should we be thinking about a step down as you get closer?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no. We have to have every pilot trained to sit in every cockpit, and so it's all or nothing. It is the way that this has been presented to us. Now we don't know exactly what training requirements Boeing in the FAA and Southwest would ultimately work o
componenttext: No, no. We have to have every pilot trained to sit in every cockpit, and so it's all or nothing. It is the way that this has been presented to us. Now we don't know exactly what training requirements Boeing in the FAA and Southwest would ultimately work out, but we can't wait that long to develop a training program and then get all of our pilots through it. So no, there'll be a day and we'll -- one day we'll be flying 50 Classics, and the next day we'll be flying 0.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That will be a hard stop.
componenttext: Okay. That will be a hard stop.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it will be a hard stop, and so in reference to Julie's earlier question, that's really the task at hand is to figure out how to smoothly do that and I'm confident we can. It will be painful, but we'll try it at least seasonally. It steps down post-La
componenttext: Yes, it will be a hard stop, and so in reference to Julie's earlier question, that's really the task at hand is to figure out how to smoothly do that and I'm confident we can. It will be painful, but we'll try it at least seasonally. It steps down post-Labor Day. So we have less flying in September than we do early August anyway. So we'll manage it, and there'll be a little bit of pain, but hopefully, we'll be able to contain that and get over it and then by a year later, they'll all be behind us.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, I think the way to think about it as we -- when we put the last AirTran aircraft down at the end of '14, we put them down in a lump, and we began a new schedule the next day and that is exactly the way we're going to manage this.
componenttext: David, I think the way to think about it as we -- when we put the last AirTran aircraft down at the end of '14, we put them down in a lump, and we began a new schedule the next day and that is exactly the way we're going to manage this.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: And I think Bob makes -- I'm so glad you mentioned that because the point is we have air practice of this and know how to do it and I don't think the world knew the thing. Now we knew it internally, but we got through it, and everything worked out just fine. So I think everything -- like I said, I think we can manage it, and I'm not overly concerned about it.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Shifting gears a little bit. Long Beach and also small new city opened, but can you talk a little bit -- obviously, well established in California, how does Long Beach fit in? Is that somewhere you'd like to turn into more full size capacity? Or wha
componenttext: Okay. Shifting gears a little bit. Long Beach and also small new city opened, but can you talk a little bit -- obviously, well established in California, how does Long Beach fit in? Is that somewhere you'd like to turn into more full size capacity? Or what happens there?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we're ecstatic to get a foothold into Long Beach here. So we had no avenue for a long time, and so just to be able to have a modest schedule to Oakland is great. The airport interacts really well with our other L.A. area service. So I don't
componenttext: Well, I think we're ecstatic to get a foothold into Long Beach here. So we had no avenue for a long time, and so just to be able to have a modest schedule to Oakland is great. The airport interacts really well with our other L.A. area service. So I don't -- we don't feel like there'll be cannibalism or anything like that. So I think this will really be new traffic for us. Obviously, there are constraints. We'd love to have more flights over time. I don't think you're going to -- I don't see a case where we would add dozens and dozens of additional flights, but if we could get another 2 another 4 over time, I think that would be wonderful. Because I think the traffic is there. Our bookings look good. We're really happy with the traffic build so far, and we're looking forward to starting service.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you probably know this, David, but we're the #1 airline in the 5-county area among the 4 airports. So I think this will really be awesome. We'll be able to provide more flexibility to customers to go out of one airport and back to another, and if we c
componenttext: And you probably know this, David, but we're the #1 airline in the 5-county area among the 4 airports. So I think this will really be awesome. We'll be able to provide more flexibility to customers to go out of one airport and back to another, and if we can get more slots, we would love to do that.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then if I can sneak one last one in about in terms of geography and RASM performance.  Can you kind of -- I mean, I would think kind of California best sort of Houston worse. Is that right? Or is it just any color on what you're seeing around the country?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're seeing California as strong, and we're seeing just general strength on across the network. And as we've called out before, just we have had a high percentage of our markets under development over the last year. So some of those -- the markets that h
componenttext: We're seeing California as strong, and we're seeing just general strength on across the network. And as we've called out before, just we have had a high percentage of our markets under development over the last year. So some of those -- the markets that have come on more recently, those are ramping up, now general strength has caused us.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think you're referring, I guess, to oil and gas, and Houston looks fantastic. Midland looks fantastic. So it's -- our business has held up quite well. I think it would be fair to say that it is not as strong as it was, but it's still really strong.
componenttext: And I think you're referring, I guess, to oil and gas, and Houston looks fantastic. Midland looks fantastic. So it's -- our business has held up quite well. I think it would be fair to say that it is not as strong as it was, but it's still really strong. So I feel real good about that. But I agree with Tammy's first reaction, which is it's mostly a function of where we have developing markets. So I think our strength is very, very broad and very consistent across the U.S. And again, we're really pleased. We're pleased with our network. It's been under construction for years, and the results look really good. Revenue management has done a phenomenal job in a very competitive environment. And the marketing, I think, is just -- no one's asked us about it. But I think the marketing and the messaging has been absolutely superb, presenting Southwest competitive advantages in a very clear and colorful way. And they're going to continue on that course, and I think it's going to continue to drive strong revenues for us as well.

componenttext: Absolute -- absolute performance. Yes, it's very good. It's not as good as it was.

componenttext: Right, okay. That's what I was trying to make sure that I --

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've been clear about that, but it is still very, very good and the same applies to Houston.
componenttext: We've been clear about that, but it is still very, very good and the same applies to Houston.

componenttext: You bet, Conor. No, we really don't have a comment on that, and we'll await to see what the government approval process reveals. And if their assets that are for sale, we'll, obviously, do our duty and take a look at them but otherwise, I don't have any comment.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from David Koenig with the Associated Press.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from David Koenig with the Associated Press.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gary, you said just a minute ago that Houston and Midland are performing, I think, "fantastic" was the word you used, right? That seems to be very different from United's experience right now in Houston. So why are you doing well there and they are not? I
componenttext: Gary, you said just a minute ago that Houston and Midland are performing, I think, "fantastic" was the word you used, right? That seems to be very different from United's experience right now in Houston. So why are you doing well there and they are not? Is it a different type of passenger? Or what can you say to explain that?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I -- we don't really compare ourselves to United first of all. So I don't know that I have an explanation. You might ask United that question. But we have had great success in Houston in particular over the past 4 years, as we have been working with
componenttext: Well, I -- we don't really compare ourselves to United first of all. So I don't know that I have an explanation. You might ask United that question. But we have had great success in Houston in particular over the past 4 years, as we have been working with the City to reestablish international service at Houston Hobby. That generated a significant amount of grassroot support locally to convince the City to add that service, which we are very pleased with. What we have discovered at the time when we started this in 2012 is that the airfares, especially internationally out of Bush were extraordinarily high, double, in fact, the airfares compared to even to Chicago on the same airline to point south. So I think what we've been able to do is build a brand new 5 gate terminal and the City of Houston and the community are very excited about that. We've been able to add a lot of new flights at lower fares, and the community has been very excited about that. And our low cost are such that we can offer that very profitably. We have a decade long business built up in Houston, including connecting it to Midland and we just had a real strong franchise there. We have a lot of loyal customers. We have a lot of Rapid Rewards members. So anywhere from 1/3 to 40% of our customers fly on us on business. So I can assure you it's not because we don't have business customers, we probably carry more business customers in the United States than any other airline. But I would just attribute it again to great service by our people, the great network that we offer. they're offering a great product, excellent on-time performance. And we've really made a very significant investment in the community, and I think the community is pleased with that.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And how can you say -- how much it would be what you're seeing there is due to the international flying you're now doing out of Hobby?
componenttext: And how can you say -- how much it would be what you're seeing there is due to the international flying you're now doing out of Hobby?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think international component in fairness to your question is relatively small. I believe, Bob, we've got about 160 daily departures. So what, 5% of that would be international.
componenttext: I think international component in fairness to your question is relatively small. I believe, Bob, we've got about 160 daily departures. So what, 5% of that would be international.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right.
componenttext: Right.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it's small, but it's new product, it's exciting. It causes people in Houston to take notice and maybe to try Southwest when they haven't flown on us in a while. So there's a halo effect. If you look back, Bob, over a 5-year time period, we've added qui
componenttext: So it's small, but it's new product, it's exciting. It causes people in Houston to take notice and maybe to try Southwest when they haven't flown on us in a while. So there's a halo effect. If you look back, Bob, over a 5-year time period, we've added quite a few new domestic nonstops as well. I want to say we've added Newark and LaGuardia, Boston. And I'm sure there are more, David, that I just can't recall, but I guess the point is we are growing in Houston. We've made a very significant commitment. We're adding new product where our people are doing a great job, and we just have a lot of momentum. So I don't know how that compares to our competitors in the market. But I don't sense that they have momentum and you [indiscernible] talk to them to figure out why that is, I guess.

componenttextpreview: Well, I'll let Tammy explain that, but we are predicting positive unit revenues in the second quarter. So we were actually slightly positive, although, in fairness, I call it flat, but we were actually up 0.1%. So I'm not answering your question literally
componenttext: Well, I'll let Tammy explain that, but we are predicting positive unit revenues in the second quarter. So we were actually slightly positive, although, in fairness, I call it flat, but we were actually up 0.1%. So I'm not answering your question literally, but it's a little more complicated than that. But I would say that the substitutive answer to your question is we're already seeing that. Tammy, do you want to explain?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So are you -- if you're referring to our yields per revenue passenger mile, I would just attribute that to as we mentioned earlier in the call where we are continuing to see a very competitive environment. And I would characterize that as weak. but w
componenttext: Yes. So are you -- if you're referring to our yields per revenue passenger mile, I would just attribute that to as we mentioned earlier in the call where we are continuing to see a very competitive environment. And I would characterize that as weak. but we've been offsetting that with strong demand for our service and so that's netting to -- we had a flat revenue performance in the first quarter. And then as we've got it, we are expecting that to term positive here in the second quarter based on our current trends. So I don't know that I can specifically answer when we are going to see our deals turn positive, but what we're really focused on, of course,  is our unit revenues. And our outlook for unit revenues is  favorable here in the second quarter.

componenttext: Great. I guess 2, 3 follow-ups. One, has the airport where capacity has exceeded demand changed? Or is it the same that it's been referred to over the past several months? And then secondly, I guess how could you -- could you characterize corporate bookings in particular?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, I would say that our -- that the main thing that's happening -- I don't know how much of the analyst call you listened to but the main thing that's been happening over the course of the last 12 months is that we had grown aggressively in 2014 a
componenttext: Well, yes, I would say that our -- that the main thing that's happening -- I don't know how much of the analyst call you listened to but the main thing that's been happening over the course of the last 12 months is that we had grown aggressively in 2014 and 2015 and added a lot of new markets. So let's call those developing markets. Those markets have begun to mature, and I think that addresses your question about capacity exceeding demand. So virtually all of our markets now are performing well, where we feel pretty good about the capacity that we have relative to the demand and the markets where we are continuing to see -- which are very many, but those markets where we're seeing softness, they're the same culprits. So they're closely in that development stage. They're new.  We're creating awareness with a customers, trying to get people to fly us and that's all very, very expected. There are a fewer of those today than there were a year ago.

componenttext: The Boeing is -- has told us, and I believe they've stated publicly that they are comfortable with their contractual commitment with us is of the third quarter of next year. There have been rumors that they might actually have the aircraft earlier and obviously, we continue to have conversation with Boeing. But our plan, which we reiterated this morning with our Classic announcement is that we'll plan to put it into revenue service after Labor Day next year. So we are anxious to get our hands on the airplane and put it through its proving grounds and get all of our training done in advance of that but that will be our plans. But as far as we know, so far everything looks really good. It looks like it's going to be a great airplane.
